Pakistan had also turned increasingly [[jingoism|jingoistic]] and militaristic against East Pakistan and India when the Pakistani news media reported the complexity of the situation in the East, though the reactions from Pakistan's news media pundits were mixed.{{cite news|last1=Ahmad|first1=Dawood|title=Rethinking the big lies from 1971 – The Express Tribune|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/307145/rethinking-the-big-lies-from-1971/|accessdate=23 December 2016|work=The Express Tribune|agency=The Express Tribune|publisher=The Express Tribune, Ahmad|date=16 December 2011}}{{cite news|last1=Ahmed|first1=Khalid|title=Pakistan,1971|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/opinion/columns/pakistan-1971-2/|accessdate=23 December 2016|work=The Indian Express|agency=Indian Express|publisher=Indian Express, 1971|date=26 December 2013}} By the end of September 1971, a [[propaganda]] campaign, possibly orchestrated by elements within the [[Government of Pakistan]], resulted in stickers endorsing ''Crush India'' becoming a standard feature on the rear windows of vehicles in [[Rawalpindi]], [[Islamabad]] and [[Lahore]]; this soon spread to the rest of West Pakistan. By October, other stickers proclaimed ''Hang the Traitor'' in an apparent reference to Sheikh Mujibur Rahman.{{cite web|url=http://www.icdc.com/~paulwolf/pakistan/farland26oct1971.htm|title=New Twist In "Crush India" Propaganda Campaign|publisher=US Department of State Telegram|date=26 October 1971|accessdate=29 September 2011}} By the first week of December, the conservative [[Newspapers in Pakistan|print media]] outlets in the country had published ''[[jihad]]'' related materials to boost the recruitment in the military.{{cite news|last1=Editorial|title=1971 'Jihad': Print ads from West Pakistan|url=http://www.dawn.com/news/1151200|accessdate=23 December 2016|work=DAWN.COM|agency=Dawn newspaper|publisher=Dawn newspaper, 2014|date=16 December 2014}} == India's official engagement with Pakistan == === Objective === [[File:Bangladesh 1971 Liberation.jpg|thumb|250px|Illustration showing military units and troop movements during operations in the Eastern sector of the war.]] By the end of April 1971, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi had asked the Indian Army chief General Sam Manekshaw if he was ready to go to war with Pakistan.{{cite news|last1=Dikshit|first1=Sandeep|title=How he and his men won those wars|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/How-he-and-his-men-won-those-wars/article15250477.ece|accessdate=24 December 2016|work=The Hindu|date=28 June 2008}}http://www.economist.com/node/11661408 According to Manekshaw's own personal account, he refused, citing the onset of [[Monsoon in India|monsoon season]] in East Pakistan and also the fact that the army tanks were being refitted.{{cite news|last1=Editorial Obituary|title=Sam Manekshaw: Sam Manekshaw, soldier, died on June 27th, aged 94|url=http://www.economist.com/node/11661408|accessdate=24 December 2016|work=The Economist|agency=The Economist|publisher=The Economist, 2008|date=3 July 2008}} He offered his resignation, which Gandhi declined. He then said he could guarantee victory if she would allow him to prepare for the conflict on his terms, and set a date for it; Gandhi accepted his conditions.{{citation |title=Sam Manekshaw |url=http://www.economist.com/obituary/displayStory.cfm?story_id=11661408 |newspaper=The Economist |issue=5 July 2008 |accessdate=7 July 2008|page=107}}Manekshaw, SHFJ. (11 Nov 1998). "Lecture at Defence Services Staff College on Leadership and Discipline" (Appendix V) in Singh (2002)''Field Marshal Sam Manekshaw, M.C. – Soldiering with Dignity''. In reality, Gandhi was well aware of the difficulties of a hasty military action, but she needed to get the military's views to satisfy her hawkish colleagues and the public opinion, which were critical of India's restraint.{{citation |first=Srinath |last=Raghavan |title=Soldiers, Statesmen, and India's Security Policy |journal=India Review |volume=11 |issue=2 |pages=116–133 |doi=10.1080/14736489.2012.674829 |subscription=yes|year=2012 }} By November 1971, an Indian-Pakistani war seemed inevitable. The [[Soviet Union]] reportedly [[Rodionov message|warned Pakistan against the war]], which they termed as "suicidal course for Pakistan's unity."{{rp|part-3}} Despite this warning, in November 1971, thousands of people led by conservative Pakistani politicians marched in Lahore and across Pakistan, calling for Pakistan to ''Crush India''.{{cite web|url=http://www.icdc.com/~paulwolf/pakistan/lahore9nov1971.jpg|title=Anti-India Demonstration and Procession|publisher=US Department of State Telegram|date=9 November 1971|accessdate=29 September 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.docstrangelove.com/uploads/1971/po/19711130_po_crush_india.pdf|title=Crush India|publisher=Pakistan Observer|date=30 November 1971|accessdate=29 September 2011}} India responded by starting a massive buildup of the Indian Army on the western borders; the army waited until December, when the drier ground in the East would have made for easier operations and the [[Himalayas|Himalayan]] passes would have been closed by snow, preventing any Chinese intervention.{{cite book|last1=Mohiuddin|first1=Yasmeen Niaz|title=Pakistan: A Global Studies Handbook|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-85109-801-9 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=OTMy0B9OZjAC&pg=PA174&q=India%20China%201971%20himalayas%20december|accessdate=24 December 2016|language=en|year=2007}}{{rp|174–175}} On 23 November, President Yahya Khan declared a [[state of emergency]] in all of Pakistan and told his people to prepare for war.{{cite web|url=http://www.warchat.org/history-asia/indo-pakistani-war-of-1971.html|title=Indo-Pakistani War of 1971|accessdate=20 October 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090823055450/http://www.warchat.org/history-asia/indo-pakistani-war-of-1971.html|archive-date=23 August 2009|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} On the evening of 3 December, at about 5:40 pm,{{cite web |url=http://www.subcontinent.com/1971war/declared.html |title=War is Declared |website=subcontinent.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091007002645/http://www.subcontinent.com/1971war/declared.html |archive-date=7 October 2009 |access-date=20 October 2009}}{{self-published inline|date=July 2015}} the [[Pakistan Air Force]] (PAF) launched surprise pre-emptive strikes on eleven airfields in north-western India, including [[Agra]], which was {{convert|300|mi|km}} from the border.{{cite book|last1=Davies|first1=Peter E.|title=F-104 Starfighter Units in Combat|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=978-1-78096-314-3|url=https://books.google.com/?id=NFebCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA83&q=operation%20Chengiz%20Khan|accessdate=24 December 2016|language=en|date=2014-11-20}}{{rp|82–83}} At the time of this attack, the [[Taj Mahal]] had been camouflaged with a forest of twigs and leaves and draped with burlap, because its marble glowed like a white beacon in the moonlight.{{cite news |title=Bangladesh: Out of War, a Nation Is Born |url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,878969,00.html |work=Time |date=20 December 1971 |accessdate=20 October 2009 |subscription=yes}} These preemptive strikes, known as [[Operation Chengiz Khan]], were inspired by the success of Israeli [[Operation Focus]] in the [[Arab]]–Israeli [[Six-Day War]]. Unlike the Israeli attack on Arab airbases in 1967, which involved a large number of Israeli planes, Pakistan flew no more than 50 planes to India.{{rp|82}}"Trying to catch the Indian Air Force napping, Yahya Khan, launched a Pakistani version of Israel's 1967 air blitz in hopes that one rapid attack would cripple India's far superior air power. But India was alert, Pakistani pilots were inept, and Yahya's strategy of scattering his thin air force over a dozen air fields was a bust!", p. 34, ''Newsweek'', 20 December 1971 In an address to the nation on radio that same evening, Prime Minister Gandhi held that the air strikes were a declaration of war against India{{cite magazine |title=India and Pakistan: Over the Edge |url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,910155,00.html |magazine=Time |date=13 December 1971 |accessdate=20 October 2009 |subscription=yes}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/december/3/newsid_2519000/2519133.stm|title=1971: Pakistan intensifies air raids on India|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=20 October 2009|date=3 December 1971}} and the [[Indian Air Force]] (IAF) responded with initial air strikes that very night. These expanded to massive retaliatory air strikes the next morning.{{cite web|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/india/sqn-5.htm|title=Indian Air Force. Squadron 5, Tuskers|website=Global Security|accessdate=20 October 2009}} This air action marked the official start of the Indo-Pakistani War of 1971; Prime Minister Gandhi ordered the immediate mobilisation of troops and launched a full-scale invasion of Pakistan.{{rp|333}} This involved Indian forces in massive [[East Pakistan Air Operations, 1971|coordinated air]], sea and land assaults on Pakistan from all fronts.{{cite book|last1=Garver|first1=John W.|title=China's Quest: The History of the Foreign Relations of the People's Republic of China|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-026106-1|url=https://books.google.com/?id=xvuuCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA333&q=indian%20attack%20on%20pakistan%201971|accessdate=24 December 2016|language=en|date=2015-12-01}}{{rp|333}} The main Indian objective on the Eastern front was to capture Dacca, and on the Western front was to prevent Pakistan from entering Indian soil. There was no Indian intention of conducting any major offensive into Pakistan to dismember it into different states. === Naval hostilities === {{main|Indo-Pakistani Naval War of 1971}} [[File:Ussdiablo.jpg|thumb|250px|Pakistan's {{ship|PNS|Ghazi}} sank off the fairway [[buoy]] of [[Visakhapatnam]] near the eastern coast of India, making it the first submarine casualty in the waters around the [[Indian subcontinent]]. ]] Unlike the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1965|1965 war]], the [[NHQ (Pakistan Navy)|Navy NHQ]] staffers and commanders of the [[Pakistan Navy]] knew very well that the Navy was ill-prepared for the naval conflict with India.{{cite book|last=Goldrick|first=James|title=No Easy Answers|year=1997|publisher=Lancer's Publications and Distributors|location=New Delhi|isbn=978-1-897829-02-8|url=https://books.google.com/?id=6XW7kKHQeQoC&pg=PA45}}{{rp|65}} The Pakistan Navy was in no condition of fighting an offensive war in deep sea against the [[Indian Navy]], and neither was it in a condition to mount serious defence against Indian Navy's seaborne encroachment.{{cite book|url=http://www.navy.gov.au/sites/default/files/documents/PIAMA02.pdf|title=No Easy Answers|last1=Goldrick|first1=James|date=1997|publisher=Sona Printers, India|isbn=1 897829 02 7|location=New Delhi, India|format=PDF|accessdate=24 December 2016}}{{rp|75–76}} In the western theatre of the war, the Indian Navy's [[Western Naval Command]] under [[Vice admiral|Vice Admiral]] [[Sourendra Nath Kohli|S.N. Kohli]], successfully launched a surprise attack on [[Port of Karachi|Karachi port]] on the night of 4/5 December 1971 under the codename [[Operation Trident (Indo-Pakistani War)|''Trident'']]. The naval attack involving the [[Soviet Navy|Soviet]]-built [[Osa-class missile boat|Osa missile boats]] sank the Pakistan Navy's [[destroyer]] {{ship|PNS|Khaibar|1956|6}} and [[Minesweeper (ship)|minesweeper]] {{ship|PNS|Muhafiz}} while {{ship|PNS|Shah Jahan|DD-962|6}} was also badly damaged. Pakistani naval sources reported that about 720 Pakistani sailors were killed or wounded, and Pakistan lost reserve fuel and many commercial ships, thus crippling the Pakistan Navy's further involvement in the conflict.{{rp|85–87}} In retaliation, the Pakistan Navy submarines, {{ship|PNS|Hangor|S131|2}}, ''Mangro'', and ''Shushuk'', began their operations to seek out the major Indian warships.{{rp|86–95}}Seapower: A Guide for the Twenty-first Century By Geoffrey Till page 179 On 9 December 1971, ''Hangor'' sank {{INS|Khukri|F149|6}}, inflicting 194 Indian casualties, and this attack was the first submarine kill since [[World War II]].{{cite book|last1=Branfill-Cook|first1=Roger|title=Torpedo: The Complete History of the World's Most Revolutionary Naval Weapon|publisher=Seaforth Publishing|isbn=9781848322158|url=https://books.google.com/?id=9lquBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA229&q=ins%20khukri%20world%20war%20II%20This%20was%20the%20first%20submarine%20kill%20since%20%5B%5BWorld%20War%20II%5D%5D|accessdate=24 December 2016|language=en|date=2014-08-27}}{{rp|229}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bharat-rakshak.com/NAVY/History/1971War/44-Attacks-On-Karachi.html |title=Trident, Grandslam and Python: Attacks on Karachi |website=Bharat Rakshak |accessdate=20 October 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090926174134/http://www.bharat-rakshak.com/NAVY/History/1971War/44-Attacks-On-Karachi.html |archivedate=26 September 2009 }} The [[INS Khukri (F149)#Incident|sinking of INS ''Khukri'']] was followed by another Indian attack on Karachi port on the night of 8/9 December 1971 under the codename [[Operation Python|''Python'']]. A [[Squadron (naval)|squadron]] of Indian Navy's Osa missile boats approached the Karachi port and launched a series of Soviet-acquired [[P-15 Termit|Styx missiles]], that resulted in further destruction of reserve fuel tanks and the sinking of three Pakistani merchant ships, as well as foreign ships docked in Karachi.{{cite web|last1=Shabir|first1=Usman|title=The Second Missile Attack " PakDef Military Consortium|url=http://pakdef.org/the-second-missile-attack/|website=pakdef.org|publisher=Pakistan Defence, Usman|accessdate=24 December 2016}} The Pakistan Air Force did not attack the Indian Navy ships, and confusion remained the next day when the civilian pilots of [[Pakistan International Airlines|Pakistan International]], acting as [[reconnaissance]] war pilots, misidentified {{ship|PNS|Zulfiqar|K265|6}} and the air force [[Friendly fire|attacked its own warship]], inflicting major damages and killing several officers on board.{{cite web|url=http://defencejournal.com/may98/fightergap2.htm |title=Defence Notes |publisher=defencejournal.com |accessdate=April 25, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120101020717/http://www.defencejournal.com/may98/fightergap2.htm |archivedate= 1 January 2012 |df= }} In the eastern theatre of the war, the Indian [[Eastern Naval Command]], under Vice Admiral [[Nilakanta Krishnan]], completely isolated East Pakistan by a [[naval blockade]] in the [[Bay of Bengal]], trapping the Eastern Pakistan Navy and eight foreign merchant ships in their ports.{{rp|82–83}} From 4 December onwards, the aircraft carrier {{INS|Vikrant|R11|6}} was deployed, and its [[Hawker Sea Hawk|Sea Hawk]] fighter-bombers attacked many coastal towns in East Pakistan, including Chittagong and [[Cox's Bazar]].{{cite book|last=Olsen|first=John Andreas|title=Global Air Power|year=2011|publisher=Potomac Books|isbn=978-1-59797-680-0|page=237}} Pakistan countered the threat by sending the submarine {{ship|PNS|Ghazi}}, which [[Sinking of PNS Ghazi|sank]] en route under mysterious circumstances off [[Visakhapatnam]]'s coast.{{cite news| url=http://www.hindu.com/mp/2006/12/02/stories/2006120202090100.htm|location=Chennai, India |work=The Hindu|title=Remembering our war heroes|date=2 December 2006}}[http://www.rediff.com/news/2007/jan/22inter.htm 'Does the US want war with India?']. Rediff.com (31 December 2004). Retrieved on 14 April 2011. Due to high number of defections, the Navy relied on deploying the [[Pakistan Marines]] - led by [[Rear Admiral]] [[Leslie Mungavin]] - where they had to conduct [[Riverine Warfare|riverine operations]] against the Indian Army, but they too suffered major losses, mainly due to their lack of understanding of [[expeditionary warfare]] and the [[Geography of Bangladesh|wet terrain]] of East Pakistan.{{cite web|last1=Pike|first1=John|title=Pakistan Marines (PM)|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/pakistan/marines.htm|website=www.globalsecurity.org|publisher=Global security, Marines|accessdate=24 December 2016}} [[File:INS Vikrant (R11) launches an Alize aircraft during Indo-Pakistani War of 1971.jpg|thumbnail|Indian aircraft carrier {{INS|Vikrant|R11|6}} launches an [[Breguet Alizé|Alize aircraft]]]] The damage inflicted on the Pakistan Navy stood at 7 [[gunboat]]s, 1 minesweeper, 1 submarine, 2 destroyers, 3 patrol crafts belonging to the [[coast guard]], 18 cargo, supply and communication vessels; and large-scale damage inflicted on the naval base and docks in the coastal town of Karachi. Three merchant navy ships – ''Anwar Baksh'', ''Pasni'' and ''Madhumathi'' –{{cite web|url=http://www.irfc-nausena.nic.in/irfc/ezine/Trans2Trimph/chapters/39_transfer%20of%20ships1.htm |title=Utilisation of Pakistan merchant ships seized during the 1971 war |publisher=Irfc-nausena.nic.in |accessdate=27 July 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120301204938/http://www.irfc-nausena.nic.in/irfc/ezine/Trans2Trimph/chapters/39_transfer%20of%20ships1.htm |archivedate=1 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }} and ten smaller vessels were captured.{{cite web|title=Damage Assesment[sic] – 1971 Indo-Pak Naval War |website=B. Harry |url=http://www.orbat.com/site/cimh/navy/kills(1971)-2.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=20 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100508210258/http://orbat.com/site/cimh/navy/kills%281971%29-2.pdf |archivedate=8 May 2010 |df=dmy }} Around 1900 personnel were lost, while 1413 servicemen were captured by Indian forces in Dacca.{{cite web|title=Military Losses in the 1971 Indo-Pakistani War |website=Venik |url=http://www.aeronautics.ru/archive/vif2_project/indo_pak_war_1971.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20020225045411/http://www.aeronautics.ru/archive/vif2_project/indo_pak_war_1971.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=25 February 2002 |access-date=30 May 2005 |df=dmy-all }} According to one Pakistani scholar, [[Tariq Ali]], Pakistan lost half its navy in the war.{{cite book |author=[[Tariq Ali]] |year=1983 |title=Can Pakistan Survive? The Death of a State |publisher=Penguin Books |page=95 |isbn=978-0-14-022401-6 |quote=In a two-week war, Pakistan lost half its navy, a quarter of its air force and a third of its army.}} === Air operations === {{main|East Pakistan Air Operations, 1971}} After the sneak attack, the PAF adopted a defensive stance in response to the Indian retaliation. As the war progressed, the IAF continued to battle the PAF over conflict zones, but the number of sorties flown by the PAF decreased day–by–day.Jon Lake, "Air Power Analysis: Indian Airpower", ''World Air Power Journal'', Volume 12Group Captain M. Kaiser Tufail, "Great Battles of the Pakistan Airforce" and "Pakistan Air Force Combat Heritage" (pafcombat) et al., Feroze sons, {{ISBN|969-0-01892-2}} The IAF flew 4,000 sorties while the PAF offered little in retaliation, partly because of the paucity of non-Bengali technical personnel. This lack of retaliation has also been attributed to the deliberate decision of the PAF's [[AHQ (Pakistan Air Force)|Air AHQ]] to cut its losses, as it had already incurred huge losses in the conflict in the liberation war in the East.{{cite web|url=http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?frd/cstdy:@field(DOCID+in0189)|title=Indo-Pakistani conflict|work=Library of Congress Country Studies|accessdate=20 October 2009}} The PAF avoided making contacts with the Indian Navy after the latter raided the port of Karachi twice, but the PAF did retaliate by bombing [[Okha, India|Okha]] harbour, destroying the fuel tanks used by the boats that had attacked.{{cite web |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/pakistan/air-force-combat.htm |title=Pakistan Air Force Combat Experience |publisher=Globalsecurity.org |access-date=27 July 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.paffalcons.com/gallery/aviation-art/syed-hussaini/trauma-and-reconstruction.php|title=Picture Gallery – Aviation Art by Group Captain Syed Masood Akhtar Hussaini|publisher=PAF Falcons|accessdate=27 July 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110830105254/http://www.paffalcons.com/gallery/aviation-art/syed-hussaini/trauma-and-reconstruction.php|archivedate=30 August 2011|df=dmy-all}} In the East, [[List of Pakistan Air Force squadrons|No. 14 Squadron Tail Choppers]] under [[Squadron Leader]] [[Parvaiz Mehdi Qureshi|PQ Mehdi]], who was taken as [[Prisoner of War|POW]], was destroyed, putting the Dhaka air defence out of commission and resulting in Indian [[air superiority]] in the East. At the end of the war, PAF pilots made successful daring escapes from East Pakistan to neighbouring [[Myanmar|Burma]]; many PAF personnel had already left the East for Burma on their own before Dacca was overrun by the Indian military in December 1971.{{cite web|last1=Khan|first1=Sher|title=Last Flight from East Pakistan|url=http://www.defencejournal.com/2001/feb/last-flight.htm|website=www.defencejournal.com|publisher=Defence Journal, 2001|accessdate=24 December 2016}} ===Indian attacks on Pakistan=== As Indian Army tightened its grip in the East Pakistan, the Indian Air Force continued with its attacks against Pakistan as the campaign developed into a series of daylight anti-airfield, anti-radar, and close-support attacks by fighter jets, with night attacks against airfields and strategic targets by [[English Electric Canberra|Canberras]] and [[Antonov An-12|An-12s]], while Pakistan responded with similar night attacks with its [[Martin B-57 Canberra|B-57s]] and [[Lockheed C-130 Hercules|C-130]]s.{{cite book|last1=Bowman|first1=Martin|title=Cold War Jet Combat: Air-to-Air Jet Fighter Operations 1950–1972|publisher=Pen and Sword|isbn=9781473874633|url=https://books.google.com/?id=QleqCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA107&lpg=PA107&q=While%20India's%20grip%20on%20what%20had%20been%20East%20Pakistan%20tightened%2C%20the%20IAF%20continued%20to%20press%20home%20attacks%20against%20Pakistan|accessdate=24 December 2016|language=en|date=2016-01-30}}{{rp|107–108}} The PAF deployed its primary [[air superiority]] aircraft, the [[Shenyang J-6|F-6s]], mainly on defensive [[combat air patrol]] missions over their own bases, leaving the PAF unable to conduct effective offensive operations.{{rp|107–108}} The IAF's raids damaged one [[United States Air Force|USAF]] and one [[United Nations|UN]] aircraft in Dacca, while a [[Royal Canadian Air Force|RCAF]] [[de Havilland Canada DHC-4 Caribou|DHC-4 Caribou]] was destroyed in [[Islamabad]], along with the USAF's [[Beechcraft L-23 Seminole|Beech U-8]] owned by the [[United States military|US military]]'s liaison chief [[Brigadier-General]] [[Chuck Yeager]].{{rp|107}}{{cite web|last1=Simha|first1=Rakesh Krishnan|title=How India brought down the US' supersonic man|url=http://in.rbth.com/articles/2012/01/17/how_india_brought_down_the_us_supersonic_man_14208|website=Russia & India Report|publisher=Russia & India Report|accessdate=24 December 2016|language=en-IN|date=17 January 2012}} Sporadic raids by the IAF continued against PAF forward air bases in Pakistan until the end of the war, and interdiction and close-support operations were maintained.{{rp|107}} One of the most successful air raids by India into West Pakistan happened on 8 December 1971, when Indian Hunter aircraft from the [[Pathankot Air Force Station|Pathankot]]-based 20 Squadron, attacked the Pakistani base in [[PAF Base Murid|Murid]] and destroyed 5 [[North American F-86 Sabre|F-86]] aircraft on the ground. This was confirmed by Pakistan's military historian, Air Commodore [[Kaiser Tufail|M Kaiser Tufail]], in his book 'In The Ring and On Its Feet - Pakistan Air Force in the 1971 Indo-Pak War'.{{cite web|author1=Vishnu Som|title=Exclusive Details Of How Air Force Raided A Pak Air Base|url=https://www.ndtv.com/india-news/exclusive-details-of-how-air-force-raided-a-pak-air-base-destroyed-jets-1803601|website=NDTV|accessdate=25 January 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180125034821/https://www.ndtv.com/india-news/exclusive-details-of-how-air-force-raided-a-pak-air-base-destroyed-jets-1803601|archivedate=25 January 2018}} The PAF played a more limited role in the operations and were reinforced by [[F-104]]s from [[Jordan]], [[Mirage III|Mirages]] from an unidentified [[Middle East]]ern ally (whose identity remains unknown), and by F-86s from [[Saudi Arabia]].{{rp|107}} Their arrival helped camouflage the extent of PAF losses, and some [[Libya]]n [[Northrop F-5|F-5s]] were reportedly deployed to [[Sargodha Airbase|Sargodha AFB]], perhaps as a potential training unit to prepare Pakistani pilots for an influx of more F-5s from Saudi Arabia.{{rp|112}} The IAF was able to conduct a wide range of missions – troop support; air combat; deep penetration strikes; para-dropping behind enemy lines; feints to draw enemy fighters away from the actual target; bombing and reconnaissance.{{rp|107}} The PAF, which was solely focused on air combat, was blown out of the subcontinent's skies within the first week of the war.{{rp|107}} Those PAF aircraft that survived took refuge at [[Iran]]ian air bases or in concrete bunkers, refusing to offer a fight.[http://in.rbth.com/blogs/2015/06/04/why_the_indian_air_force_has_a_high_crash_rate_43501 Why the Indian Air Force has a high crash rate] India flew 1,978 sorties in the East and about 4,000 in Pakistan, while the PAF flew about 30 and 2,840 at the respective fronts.{{rp|107}} More than 80 percent of IAF sorties were close-support and interdiction and about 45 IAF aircraft were lost. Pakistan lost 75 aircraft, not including any F-6s, Mirage IIIs, or the six Jordanian F-104s which failed to return to their donors. The imbalance in air losses was explained by the IAF's considerably higher sortie rate and its emphasis on ground-attack missions. === Ground operations === [[File:T-55 tanks in the Bangladesh Liberation War.jpg|thumb|250px|The [[Indian Army Armoured Corps|Indian T-55]] tanks penetrating the [[India-East Pakistan border|Indo-East Pakistan border]] towards [[Dacca]].]] Before the start of the war, the Indian Army was well organised on both fronts and enjoyed significant numerical superiority over the Pakistan Army.{{cite book|last1=Jr|first1=Karl DeRouen|last2=Heo|first2=Uk|title=Civil Wars of the World: Major Conflicts Since World War II|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=9781851099191|url=https://books.google.com/?id=nrN077AEgzMC&pg=PA596&q=pakistan%20army%201971%20India|accessdate=24 December 2016|language=en|date=2007-05-10}}{{rp|596}} The Indian Army's extraordinary war performance at both fronts brought up the prestige, confidence, and dignity that it had lost during the [[1962 Sino-Indian conflict|war with China]] in 1962.{{cite news |last1=Singh |first1=Dipender |date=27 June 2008 |title='Sam gave dignity to Army in 1971, after 1962 debacle'|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/delhi/sam-gave-dignity-to-army-in-1971-after-1962-debacle/story-s3usXYBVqUlgYGYqbFrSIO.html |work=Hindustan Times |accessdate=26 December 2016}} When the conflict started, the war immediately took a decisive turn in favour of India and their [[Mukti Bahini|Bengali rebel allies]] militarily and diplomatically.{{rp|596}} On both fronts, Pakistan launched several ground offensives, but the Indian Army held its ground and initiated well-coordinated ground operations on both fronts.{{rp|596}} Major ground attacks were concentrated on the western border by the Pakistan Army, fighting together with the Pakistan Marines in the [[Punjab|southern border]], but the Indian Army was successful in penetrating into Pakistani soil. It eventually made some quick and initial gains, including the capture of around {{convert|5795|sqmi|km2}}{{cite book |last=Nawaz |first=Shuja |title=Crossed Swords: Pakistan, Its Army, and the Wars Within |date=2008 |publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0-19-547697-2 |page=329}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=LCaAQCnO3QQC&pg=PA81&q=5000%20miles%20square%20indian%20army%201971|title=Benazir, a Profile – M. G. Chitkara|accessdate=27 July 2012|isbn=9788170247524|author1=Chitkara|first1=M. G|year=1996}} of Pakistani territory; this land gained by India in [[Azad Kashmir]], [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]] and [[Sindh]] sectors was later ceded in the [[Simla Agreement]] of 1972, as a gesture of goodwill.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Ek00fuXVz1wC&pg=PA117&q=5000%20miles%20indian%20army%201971|title=Kashmir in Conflict: India, Pakistan and the Unending War – Victoria Schofield|date=18 January 2003|accessdate=27 July 2012|isbn=9781860648984|author1=Schofield|first1=Victoria}} Casualties inflicted to Pakistan Army's [[I Corps (Pakistan)|I Corps]], [[II Corps (Pakistan)|II Corps]], and Pakistan Marines' [[Pakistan Navy Punjab Command|Punjab detachment]] were very high, and many soldiers and marines perished due to lack of operational planning and lack of coordination within the marine-army formations against Indian Army's [[Southern Command (India)|Southern]] and [[Western Command (India)|Western Commands]].{{cite book|last1=Palit|first1=Maj Gen DK|title=The Lightning Campaign: The Indo-Pakistan War, 1971|publisher=Lancer Publishers|isbn=9781897829370|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PKvmgfHewHcC&pg=PA83#v=onepage|accessdate=24 December 2016|language=en|date=2012-10-10}}{{rp|82–93}} By the time the war came to end, the army soldiers and marines were highly demoralised– both emotionally and psychologically– on the [[India-Pakistan border|western front]] and had no [[Will (philosophy)|will]] to put up a defensive fight against the approaching Indian Army soldiers.{{cite book|last1=Hasnat|first1=Syed Farooq|title=Pakistan|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=9780313346972|url=https://books.google.com/?id=yeqwIs_NoTEC&pg=PA2&q=pakistan%20army%20demoralized%201971|accessdate=24 December 2016|language=en|year=2011}}{{rp|1–2}}{{cite book|last1=Goswami|first1=Arvind|title=3 D Deceit, Duplicity & Dissimulation of U.S. Foreign Policy Towards India, Pakistan & Afghanistan|publisher=AuthorHouse|isbn=9781477257098|url=https://books.google.com/?id=amkR1LkaQmQC&pg=PA27&q=pakistan%20army%20demoralized%201971|accessdate=24 December 2016|language=en|date=2012-09-13}}{{rp|26–27}}{{Self published inline|certain=y|date=July 2018}} The War Enquiry Commission later exposed the fact that for the Pakistan Army and Pakistan Marines, the arms and training of marines, soldiers and officers were needed at every level, and every level of command.{{cite book|last1=Alam|first1=Dr Shah|title=Pakistan Army: Modernisation, Arms Procurement and Capacity Building|publisher=Vij Books India Pvt Ltd|isbn=9789381411797|url=https://books.google.com/?id=WvapCQAAQBAJ&pg=PT40&q=pakistan%20army%201971%20India|language=en|date=2012-06-12}} On 23 November 1971, the Indian Army conventionally penetrated to the eastern fronts and crossed East Pakistan's borders to join their [[Mitro Bahini|Bengali nationalist]] allies.{{cite book|last1=Nair|first1=Sreekumar|title=Interpretation|publisher=Pustak Mahal|isbn=9788122311112|url=https://books.google.com/?id=9gdHmR_6K0AC&pg=PA156&lpg=PA156&q=1965%20war%20which%20had%20emphasised%20set-piece%20battles|accessdate=24 December 2016|language=en|date=2010-03-01}}{{rp|156}} Contrary to the [[Indo-Pakistani war of 1965|1965 war]], which had emphasised set-piece battles and slow advances, this time the strategy adopted was a swift, three-pronged assault of nine infantry divisions with attached armoured units and close air support that rapidly converged on Dacca, the capital of East Pakistan.{{rp|156}} Lieutenant General [[Jagjit Singh Aurora]], the [[General Officer Commanding-in-Chief|GOC-in-C]] of the Indian Army's [[Eastern Command (India)|Eastern Command]], led the full Indian thrust into East Pakistan. As the Indian Eastern Command attacked the [[Pakistan Eastern Command]], the Indian Air Force rapidly destroyed the small air contingent in East Pakistan and put the Dacca airfield out of commission.{{rp|156}} In the meantime, the Indian Navy effectively blockaded East Pakistan.{{rp|156}} The Indian campaign's "''[[blitzkrieg]]''" techniques exploited weaknesses in the Pakistani positions and bypassed opposition; this resulted in a swift victory.{{cite book|last=Paret|first=Peter|author2=Gordon A. Craig |author3=Felix Gilbert |title=Makers of Modern Strategy: From Machiavelli to the Nuclear Age|url=https://books.google.com/?id=F0N59g93EBYC|year=1986|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-820097-0}}, pp802{{rp|802}} Faced with insurmountable losses, the Pakistani military capitulated in less than a fortnight and psychological panic spread in the Eastern Command's military leadership.{{rp|802}} Subsequently, the Indian Army encircled Dacca and issued an ultimatum to surrender in "30-minutes" time window on 16 December 1971.{{cite web|last1=Sengupta|first1=Ramananda|title=1971 War: 'I will give you 30 minutes'|url=http://www.sify.com/news/1971-war-i-will-give-you-30-minutes-news-columns-jmqlV0fcjjasi.html|website=Sify|publisher=Sify, Sengupta|accessdate=24 December 2016}} Upon hearing the ultimatum, the [[Government of East Pakistan|East-Pakistan government]] collapsed when the Lt-Gen. [[Amir Abdullah Khan Niazi|A.A.K. Niazi]] ([[General Officer Commanding-in-Chief|Cdr.]] of [[East Pakistan Military Command|Eastern Command]]) and his deputy, [[Vice-Admiral|V-Adm.]] [[Mohammad Shariff|M.S. Khan]], surrendered without offering any resistance. On 16 December 1971, Pakistan ultimately called for unilateral ceasefire and surrendered its [[Pakistani military|entire four-tier military]] to the Indian Army– hence ending the Indo-Pakistani war of 1971. On the ground, Pakistan suffered the most, with 8,000 killed and 25,000 wounded, while India only had 3,000 dead and 12,000 wounded.''The Encyclopedia of 20th Century Air Warfare'', edited by Chris Bishop (Amber publishing 1997, republished 2004 pages 384–387 {{ISBN|1-904687-26-1}}) The loss of [[Vehicle armour|armoured vehicles]] was similarly imbalanced and this finally represented a major defeat for Pakistan. === Surrender of Pakistan Eastern Command in East Pakistan === {{main|Instrument of Surrender (1971)|East Pakistan Military Command}} Officially, the Instrument of Surrender of Pakistan Eastern Command stationed in East Pakistan, was signed between the Lieutenant General Jagjit Singh Aurora, the GOC-in-C of Indian Eastern Command and Lieutenant-General A.A.K. Niazi, the Commander of the Pakistan Eastern Command, at the [[Ramna Race Course]] in Dacca at 16:31Hrs [[Indian Standard Time|IST]] on 16 December 1971.{{cite book|last1=Naseer|first1=Javed|title=The Morning Echo: An Observation of Nature and Science|publisher=iUniverse, Naseer|isbn=9781475957082|url=https://books.google.com/?id=fRoDKCXlscEC&pg=PA156&q=anti-pakistan%20anti-niazi|accessdate=24 December 2016|language=en|date=2012-10-26}}{{rp|156–157}}{{self published inline|certain=y|date=July 2018}} As the [[Surrender (military)|surrender]] was accepted silently by Lieutenant-General Aurora, the surrounding crowds on the race course started shouting [[Anti-Pakistan sentiment|anti-Pakistan]] slogans, and there were reports of abuses aimed at the surrendering commanders of Pakistani military.{{rp|157}}{{self published inline|certain=y|date=July 2018}}{{cite news|last=Nayar |first=Kuldip |date=3 February 1998 |title=Of betrayal and bungling |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/res/web/pIe/ie/daily/19980203/03450744.html |newspaper=The Indian Express |accessdate=20 October 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090823045047/http://www.indianexpress.com/res/web/pIe/ie/daily/19980203/03450744.html |archivedate=23 August 2009 }}{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=December 2017}} Hostilities officially ended at 14:30 [[Greenwich Mean Time|GMT]] on 17 December, after the [[Fall of Dhaka|fall of Dacca]] on 15 December, and India claimed large gains of territory in Pakistan (although pre-war boundaries were recognised after the war). The war confirmed the independence of [[Bangladesh]].{{rp|107}} Following the surrender, the Indian Army took approximately 90,000 Pakistani servicemen and their Bengali supporters as [[prisoners of war|POWs]], making it the largest surrender since [[World War II]].{{rp|157}}{{self published inline|certain=y|date=July 2018}} Initial counts recorded that approximately 79,676 war prisoners were uniformed personnel, and the overwhelming majority of the war prisoners were officers - most of them were from the Army and Navy, while relatively small numbers were from the Air Force and Marines; others in larger number were serving in the [[Paramilitary forces of Pakistan|paramilitary]].{{cite book|last1=Cloughley|first1=Brian|title=A History of the Pakistan Army: Wars and Insurrections|date=2016|publisher=Skyhorse Publishing, Inc.|isbn=9781631440397|url=https://books.google.com/?id=JE1kCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT280&q=Pakistani%20Prisoners%20of%20War%20%20Indian%20army|accessdate=8 August 2017|language=en}} The remaining prisoners were civilians who were either family members of the military personnel or collaborators ([[Razakars (Pakistan)|razakars]]). The [[Hamoodur Rahman Commission]] and the [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1971 Prisoners of War Investigation|POW Investigation Commission]] reports instituted by Pakistan lists the Pakistani POWs as given in the table below. Apart from soldiers, it was estimated that 15,000 Bengali civilians were also made prisoners of war.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=nuYcwYCcjpIC&pg=PA216&q=many%20pakistani%20women%20prisoners%20of%20war%20in%201971|title=Mainsprings of Indian and Pakistani Foreign Policies – S. M. Burke|accessdate=27 July 2012|isbn=9780816607204|author1=Burke|first1=S. M|year=1974}} {|class="wikitable" |- ! Inter-Service Branch !! Number of captured Pakistani POWs !! Officer Commanding |- | {{army|PAK}} || 54,154 || [[Lieutenant-General]] [[Amir Abdullah Khan Niazi]] |- | [[File:Naval Jack of Pakistan.svg|20px]] [[Pakistan Navy]]/[[Pakistan Marines]] || 1,381 || [[Rear-Admiral]] [[Mohammad Shariff]] |- | {{air force|PAK}} || 833 || [[Air Commodore]] [[Inamul Haque Khan|Inamul Haq]] |- |[[Paramilitary forces of Pakistan|Paramilitary]]/[[East Pakistan Rifles]]/[[East Pakistan Police|Police]] || 22,000 || [[Major-General]] [[Rao Farman Ali]] |- |[[Government of East Pakistan|Civil government personnel]] || 12,000 || [[Governor of East Pakistan|Governor]] [[Abdul Motaleb Malik]] |- | Total: || 90,368 || ~ |} == Foreign reaction and involvement == === United States and Soviet Union === [[File:Blood telegram.png|The [[Blood Telegram]]|thumb]] The [[Soviet Union]] sympathised with the [[East Pakistanis]], and supported the Indian Army and [[Mukti Bahini]]'s incursion against Pakistan during the war, in a broader view of recognising that the [[Independence of Bangladesh|succession]] of East Pakistan as [[People's Republic of Bangladesh|Independent Bangladesh]] would weaken the position of its rivals— the [[United states and china|United States and China]]. The Soviet Union gave assurances to India that if a confrontation with the United States or China developed, it would take counter-measures. This assurance was enshrined in the [[Indo-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Cooperation]] signed in August 1971.{{cite web|url=http://www.theworldreporter.com/2011/10/1971-india-pakistan-war-role-of-russia.html|title=1971 India Pakistan War: Role of Russia, China, America and Britain|website=The World Reporter|accessdate=30 October 2011}} However, the Indo-Soviet treaty did not mean a total commitment to every Indian position, even though the Soviet Union had accepted the Indian position during the conflict, according to author Robert Jackson.{{cite book|last1=Jackson|first1=Robert|title=South Asian Crisis: India — Pakistan — Bangla Desh|publisher=Springer|isbn=9781349041633|url=https://books.google.com/?id=tb6vCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA73&q=rodionov%20pakistan%20yahya|accessdate=22 December 2016|language=en|date=1978-06-17}}{{rp|72–73}} The Soviet Union continued its sympathetic gesture to Pakistan until mid-October 1971, when it stressed Pakistan to come up with a political settlement and affirmed its continuation of industrial aid to Pakistan.{{rp|73}} By November 1971, the [[Ambassador of the Soviet Union to Pakistan|Soviet ambassador]] to Pakistan [[Aleksei A. Rodionov|Alexei Rodionov]] directed a secretive message (''[[Rodionov message]]'') that ultimately warned Pakistan that "it will be embarking on a suicidal course if it escalates tensions in the subcontinent.{{cite book|last1=Service|first1=British Broadcasting Corporation Monitoring|title=Summary of World Broadcasts: Far East|date=1971|publisher=Monitoring Service of the British Broadcasting Corporation|location=London, UK|url=https://books.google.com/?id=0ETRAAAAMAAJ&q=rodionov|accessdate=22 December 2016|language=en}}{{rp|part-3}} The [[United States]] stood with Pakistan by supporting it morally, politically, economically and materially when [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Richard Nixon]] and his [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] [[Henry Kissinger]] refused to use rhetoric in a hopeless attempt to intervene in a large [[civil war]]. The U.S. establishment perceived to the impression that they needed Pakistan to help stop Soviet [[Great Game|influence]] in [[South Asia]] in an informal alliance with India.{{rp|281}} During the [[Cold War (1953–62)|Cold War]], Pakistan was a close [[CENTO|formal ally]] of the United States and also had [[China–Pakistan relations|close relations]] with the [[People's Republic of China]], with whom Nixon had been negotiating a [[Sino-American relations#Rapprochement|''rapprochement'']] and where he [[Nixon visit to China|intended to visit]] in February 1972.Harold H. Saunders, "What Really Happened in Bangladesh" Foreign Affairs (2014) 93#4 d Nixon feared that an Indian invasion of Pakistan would mean total Soviet domination of the region, and that it would seriously undermine the [[Balance of power (international relations)|global position]] of the United States and the regional position of America's new tactical ally, China.{{cite book|last1=VSM|first1=Brig Amar Cheema|title=The Crimson Chinar: The Kashmir Conflict: A Politico Military Perspective|publisher=Lancer Publishers|isbn=9788170623014|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Qc25BwAAQBAJ&pg=PA282&q=Nixon%20encourage%20iran%20%201971%20war%20pakistan|accessdate=27 December 2016|language=en|date=2015-03-31}}{{rp|281–282}} Nixon encouraged [[Jordan]] and [[Iran]] to send military supplies to Pakistan, while also encouraging China to increase its arms supplies to Pakistan, but all supplies were very limited.{{cite book|last1=Alvandi|first1=Roham|title=Nixon, Kissinger, and the Shah: The United States and Iran in the Cold War|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780190610685|url=https://books.google.com/?id=FJLSDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA61&q=Nixon%20encourage%20iran%20%201971%20war%20pakistan|accessdate=27 December 2016|language=en|date=November 2016}}{{rp|61}}{{cite web |url=http://coat.ncf.ca/our_magazine/links/issue47/articles/a07.htm |title=The Men Behind Yahya in the Indo-Pak War of 1971 |last=Shalom |first=Stephen R. |website=Coalition to Oppose the Arms Trade |access-date=20 October 2009}}{{self-published source|date=July 2015}} The Nixon administration also ignored reports it received of the "genocidal" activities of the Pakistani military in East Pakistan, most notably the [[Blood telegram]], and this prompted widespread criticism and condemnation - both by the [[United States Congress]] and in the international press.{{cite book|last=Hanhimäki|first=Jussi|title=The flawed architect: Henry Kissinger and American foreign policy|url=https://books.google.com/?id=pPjrpGUe7CEC|year=2004|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-517221-8}}{{cite news |last=Lewis |first=John P. |date=9 December 1971 |title=Mr. Nixon and South Asia |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1971/12/09/archives/mr-nixon-and-south-asia.html |newspaper=The New York Times |quote=The Nixon Administration's South Asia policy... is beyond redemption}} Then [[United States Ambassador to the United Nations|U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations]], [[George H.W. Bush|George Bush, Sr]], introduced a resolution in the [[United Nations Security Council|UN Security Council]] calling for a cease-fire and the withdrawal of armed forces by India and Pakistan.{{rp|73}} However, it was [[United Nations Security Council veto power|vetoed]] by the Soviet Union, and the following days witnessed the use of great pressure on the Soviets from the Nixon-Kissinger duo to get India to withdraw, but to no avail.{{cite news |date=26 December 2006 |title=1971 War: How the US tried to corner India |url=http://www.rediff.com/news/2006/dec/26claude.htm |newspaper=Rediff.com |access-date=14 April 2011}} When Pakistan's defeat in the eastern sector seemed certain, Nixon deployed [[Task Force 74]] - led by the [[aircraft carrier]] {{USS|Enterprise|CVN-65|6}} - into the [[Bay of Bengal]]. ''Enterprise'' and its escort ships arrived on station on 11 December 1971.{{cite book |last1=Rajagopalan |first1=Rajesh |last2=Mishra |first2=Atul |year=2015 |title=Nuclear South Asia: Keywords and Concepts |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p8BcCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT207 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=978-1-317-32475-1}}{{rp|xxxx}} According to a Russian documentary, the [[United Kingdom]] also deployed a carrier battle group led by the aircraft carrier {{HMS|Eagle|R05|6}} to the Bay,{{cite web |url=http://www.frontierindia.net/british-aircraft-carrier-hms-eagle-tried-to-intervene-in-1971-india-pakistan-war |title=British aircraft carrier 'HMS Eagle' tried to intervene in 1971 India – Pakistan war |website=Frontier India |date=18 December 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160110154941/http://frontierindia.net/british-aircraft-carrier-hms-eagle-tried-to-intervene-in-1971-india-pakistan-war/ |archive-date=10 January 2016 |accessdate=27 July 2012}}{{Better source|reason=citations are to an "open online students' journal" (TheWorldReporter) and a blog (Frontier India) repeating some guy's translation of a Russian-language video, there must be a scholarly history book or contemporary news report for this|date=April 2016}} on her final deployment. On 6 and 13 December, the [[Soviet Navy]] dispatched two groups of [[cruiser]]s and [[destroyer]]s from [[Vladivostok]]; they trailed US Task Force 74 into the Indian Ocean from 18 December 1971 until 7 January 1972. The Soviets also had a [[Ballistic missile submarine|nuclear submarine]] to help ward off the threat posed by the USS ''Enterprise'' task force in the Indian Ocean.{{cite web|url=http://www.bharat-rakshak.com/NAVY/History/1971War/Games.html |title=Cold war games |website=Bharat Rakshak |accessdate=20 October 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609180906/http://www.bharat-rakshak.com/NAVY/History/1971War/Games.html |archivedate=9 June 2011 |df=dmy }}{{cite news |date=11 December 2009 |title=Birth of a nation |url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/birth-of-a-nation/552795/3 |newspaper=The Indian Express |access-date=14 April 2011}} As the war progressed, it became apparent to the United States that India was going to invade and disintegrate Pakistan in a matter of weeks, therefore President Nixon spoke with the [[General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|USSR Secretary General]] [[Leonid Brezhnev]] on a [[Moscow–Washington hotline|hotline]] on 10 December, where Nixon reportedly urged Brezhnev to restrain India as he quoted: "in the strongest possible terms to restrain India with which … you [Brezhnev] have great influence and for whose actions you must share responsibility."{{cite web|title=Nixon/Kissinger Saw India as "Soviet Stooge" in 1971 South Asia Crisis|url=http://nsarchive.gwu.edu/news/20050629/|website=nsarchive.gwu.edu|publisher=George Washington University press|accessdate=24 December 2016}} After the war, the United States accepted the new [[Balance of power (international relations)|balance of power]] and recognised India as a dominant player in South Asia; the US immediately engaged in strengthening [[Indo-US Relations|bilateral relations between the two countries]] in the successive years.{{cite book|last1=Wetering|first1=Carina|title=Changing US Foreign Policy toward India|publisher=Springer|isbn=9781137548627|url=https://books.google.com/?id=iYtjDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA69&lpg=PA69&q=India%20as%20%22Soviet%20Stooge%22%20in%201971%20South%20Asia%20Crisis|accessdate=24 December 2016|language=en}}{{rp|69}} The Soviet Union, while being sympathetic to Pakistan's loss, decided to engage with Pakistan after sending an invitation through Rodionov to [[Zulfikar Ali Bhutto|Z A Bhutto]], who [[1972 Bhutto visit to Soviet Union|paid a state visit]] to the Soviet Union in 1972 to strengthen [[Pakistan-Soviet Union relations|bilateral relations]] that continued over the years.{{cite book|title=News Review on South Asia and Indian Ocean|date=1972|publisher=Institute for Defence Studies & Analyses.|url=https://books.google.com/?id=VVU8AAAAMAAJ&q=rodionov+pakistan+Bhutto|accessdate=22 December 2016|language=en}}{{rp|16}} === China and Iran === During the course of the war, [[China]] harshly criticised India for its involvement in the East Pakistan crises, and accused India of having [[Indian Century|imperialistic]] designs in South Asia.{{cite book|last1=Jayapalan|first1=N.|title=India and Her Neighbours|publisher=Atlantic Publishers & Dist|isbn=9788171569120|url=https://books.google.com/?id=sQVkYiFCrVoC&pg=PA19&q=china%201971%20indo%20pak%20war|accessdate=25 December 2016|language=en}}{{rp|19}} Before the war started, Chinese leaders and officials had long been philosophically advising the Pakistan government to make peaceful political settlements with the East Pakistani leaders, as China feared that India was secretly supporting, infiltrating, and arming the Bengali rebels against the [[Government of East Pakistan|East Pakistani government]].{{cite book|last1=Singh|first1=edited by Swaran|title=China-Pakistan strategic cooperation : Indian perspectives|date=2007|publisher=Manohar|location=New Delhi|isbn=978-8173047619}}{{rp|61}}{{cite book|last1=Jaffrelot|first1=Christophe|title=Pakistan at the Crossroads: Domestic Dynamics and External Pressures|publisher=Columbia University Press|isbn=9780231540254|url=https://books.google.com/?id=A791CwAAQBAJ&pg=PA285&q=china%201971%20indo%20pak%20war%20general|accessdate=25 December 2016|language=en}}{{rp|285}} China was also critical of the Government of East Pakistan, led by its [[Governor of East Pakistan|Governor]] Lieutenant-General Tikka Khan - which used ruthless measures to deal with the Bengali opposition - and did not endorse the Pakistani position on that issue.{{rp|285}} When the war started, China reproached India for its direct involvement and infiltration in East Pakistan.{{rp|285}} It disagreed with Pakistani President Yahya Khan's consideration of military options, and criticised [[East Pakistan Awami League]] politicians' ties with India.{{rp|285}} China reacted with great alarm when the prospects of Indian invasion of Pakistan and integration of [[Pakistan-administered Kashmir]] into their [[Indian-controlled Kashmir|side of Kashmir]], became imminent. US President Nixon encouraged China to mobilise its [[Peoples Liberation Army|armed forces]] along its border with India to discourage the Indian assault, but the Chinese did not respond to this encouragement since the Indian Army's [[Northern Command (India)|Northern Command]] was well prepared to guard the [[Line of Actual Control]], and was already engaging and making advances against the Pakistan Army's [[X Corps (Pakistan)|X Corps]] in the [[Line of Control]].{{cite book|last1=Roychoudhury|first1=H. P.|title=A Silent Patriot of Bangladesh|publisher=Partridge Publishing|isbn=9781482886887|url=https://books.google.com/?id=KpWaDQAAQBAJ&pg=PT135&q=Nixon%20encouraged%20China%20to%20mobilise%20its%20armed%20forces%20along%20its%20border|accessdate=25 December 2016|language=en}}{{rp|xxxiii}}{{self published inline|certain=y|date=July 2018}} China did not welcome the break-up of Pakistan's unity by the East Pakistani politicians, and effectively vetoed the membership of [[Bangladesh]] when it applied to the [[United Nations]] in 1972.{{cite news|title=China Recognizes Bangladesh|agency=Associated Press|publisher=The Press Courier, via Google News|location=Oxnard, California, USA|date=1 September 1975|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rnVKAAAAIBAJ&sjid=RSINAAAAIBAJ&pg=4237,20391}} China objected to admitting Bangladesh on the grounds that two [[Un resolutions|UN resolutions]] concerning Bangladesh, requiring the [[Delhi Agreement|repatriation]] of Pakistani [[Indo-Pakistani War of 1971 Prisoners of War Investigation|POWs and civilians]], had not yet been implemented.{{cite news|title=China Veto Downs Bangladesh UN Entry|agency=United Press International|date=26 August 1972|publisher=The Montreal Gazette, via Google News|location=Montreal, Quebec, Canada|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=GQsyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=w6EFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4712,6055847}} Furthermore, China was also among the last countries to [[Foreign relations of Bangladesh|recognise]] the independence of [[Bangladesh]], refusing to do so until 31 August 1975.{{cite book|last1=Chau|first1=Donovan C.|last2=Kane|first2=Thomas M.|title=China and International Security: History, Strategy, and 21st-Century Policy [3 volumes]: History, Strategy, and 21st-Century Policy|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=9781440800023|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Xo6dAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA226&q=china%20recognized%20bangladesh%201975|accessdate=26 December 2016|language=en}}{{rp|226–227}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bdsdf.org/forum/index.php?showtopic=3072|title=The Recognition Story|publisher=Bangladesh Strategic and Development Forum|accessdate=17 August 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725050939/http://www.bdsdf.org/forum/index.php?showtopic=3072|archivedate=25 July 2011|df=dmy-all}} To this date, its relations with Bangladesh are determined by the Pakistan factor.{{cite book|last1=Raghavan|first1=V. R.|title=Internal Conflicts- A Four State Analysis: India-Nepal-Sri Lanka-Myanmar|publisher=Vij Books India Pvt Ltd|isbn=9789382573418|url=https://books.google.com/?id=mv-pCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA69&q=china%20recognized%20bangladesh%201975|accessdate=26 December 2016|language=en}}{{rp|69}} During the course of the conflict, [[Iran]] also stood with Pakistan politically and diplomatically.{{rp|78–79}} It was concerned with the imminent break-up of Pakistan which, it feared, would have caused the state to [[Balkanization|fractionalise into small pieces]], ultimately resulting in Iran's encirclement by rivals. After the war, however, Iran began cementing [[India–Iran relations|ties with India]] based on mutual security co-operation.{{rp|79}}{{verification needed|date=September 2017}} At the beginning of the conflict, Iran had helped Pakistan by sheltering PAF's fighter jets and providing it with free fuel to take part in the conflict, in an attempt to keep Pakistan's regional integrity united.{{rp|80}}{{verification needed|date=September 2017}} When Pakistan called for unilateral ceasefire and the surrender was announced, the [[Mohammad Reza Pahlavi|Shah of Iran]] hastily responded by preparing the [[Iranian military]] to come up with contingency plans to forcefully invade Pakistan and annex its [[Balochistan, Pakistan|Balochistan province]] into [[Balochistan, Iran|its side of Balochistan]], by any means necessary, before anybody else did it.{{rp|79}}{{verification needed|date=September 2017}} == Aftermath == === India === The war stripped Pakistan of more than half of its population, and with nearly one-third of its army in captivity, clearly established India's military and political dominance of the subcontinent. India successfully led a diplomatic campaign to isolate Pakistan and skillfully manipulate Pakistan's supporting countries to limit the extent of support to Pakistan.{{rp|596}} In addition, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's state visit to [[United Kingdom]] and [[France]] further helped break ice with the United States, and blocked any pro-Pakistan resolution in the [[United Nations]].{{rp|596}} There was also a meeting between Prime Minister Gandhi and President Nixon in November 1971,{{clarify|date=February 2017|reason=Aftermath section should cover events after December 1971, is this a typo or in wrong section?}} where she rejected the US advice against intervening in the conflict.{{rp|596}} The victory also defined India's much broader role in foreign politics, as many countries in the world had come to realise - including the United States - that the balance of power had shifted to India as a major player in the region.{{cite book|last1=Mudiam|first1=Prithvi Ram|title=India and the Middle East|publisher=British Academic Press|isbn=9781850437031|url=https://books.google.com/?id=jiDYjw4gCzEC&pg=PA79&q=shah%20of%20iran%20and%20india%201971|accessdate=24 December 2016|language=en}}{{rp|80}}{{cite book|last1=Kemp|first1=Geoffrey|title=The East Moves West: India, China, and Asia's Growing Presence in the Middle East|publisher=Brookings Institution Press|isbn=978-0815724070|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Z-rV05oQ_4AC&pg=PA57&q=iran%20and%20india%201971|accessdate=24 December 2016|language=en}}{{rp|57}} In the wake of changing geopolitical realities, India sought to establish closer relations with regional countries such as Iran, which was a traditional ally of Pakistan.{{rp|57}} The United States itself accepted a new balance of power, and when India conducted a [[Smiling Buddha|surprise nuclear test]] in 1974, the US notified India that it had no "interest in actions designed to achieve new balance of power."{{rp|69}} In spite of the magnitude of the victory, India was surprisingly restrained in its reaction. Mostly, Indian leaders seemed pleased by the relative ease with which they had accomplished their goals—the establishment of Bangladesh and the prospect of an early return to their homeland of the 10 million Bengali refugees who were the cause of the war. In announcing the Pakistani surrender, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi declared in the Indian Parliament: {{quote|Dacca is now the free capital of a free country. We hail the people of Bangladesh in their hour of triumph. All nations who value the human spirit will recognise it as a significant milestone in man's quest for liberty.|sign=|source=}} Colonel John Gill of [[National Defense University]], US, remarks that, while India achieved a military victory, it was not able to reap the political fruits it might have hoped for in Bangladesh. After a brief 'honeymoon' phase between India and Bangladesh, [[Bangladesh–India relations|their relationship]] began to sour. India's relations with Bangladesh have remained frequently problematic and tense.{{Cite book |url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/22107538/An-Atlas-of-the-1971-India-Pakistan-War-The-Creation-Of-Bangladesh |title=An Atlas of the 1971 India – Pakistan War: The Creation of Bangladesh |last=Gill |first=John H. |publisher=National Defense University. Near East South Asia Center for Strategic Studies |year=2003 |isbn= |location=Washington DC |pages=66}}{{citation |url=https://muse.jhu.edu/login?auth=0&type=summary&url=/journals/journal_of_military_history/v069/69.2higham.html |title=An Atlas of the 1971 India – Pakistan war : the creation of Bangladesh (review) |last=Higham |first=Robin D. S. |journal=The Journal of Military History |volume=69 |number=2 |date=April 2005}} Whilst India enjoys excellent relations with Bangladesh during [[Awami League]] tenures, relations deteriorate when the [[Bangladesh Nationalist Party]] is in power. A 2014 [[Pew Research Center]] opinion poll in Bangladesh found that India was perceived as the greatest threat to Bangladesh. This was the top choice (27%) of Bangladeshis. However, 70% of Bangladeshis held a positive view of India: while 50% of Bangladeshis held a positive view of Pakistan.{{Cite web |url=http://www.pewglobal.org/2014/07/14/chapter-4-how-asians-view-each-other/|title=Chapter 4: How Asians View Each Other|website=Pew Research Center's Global Attitudes Project|access-date=2016-04-09}} === Pakistan === For Pakistan, the war was a complete and humiliating defeat, a psychological setback that came from a defeat at the hands of rival India. Pakistan lost half its population and a significant portion of its economy, and suffered setbacks to its geopolitical role in South Asia. In the post-war era, Pakistan struggled to absorb the lessons learned from the military interventions in the democratic system and the impact of the Pakistani military's failure was grave and long-lasting.{{cite web|title=Pakistan's leaders should heed the lesson of Bangladesh|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2010/aug/15/pakistan-flood-warning|website=The Guardian|accessdate=26 December 2016|date=15 August 2010}}{{cite web|title=No lessons learnt in forty years – The Express Tribune|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/307080/no-lessons-learnt-in-forty-years/|website=The Express Tribune|accessdate=26 December 2016|date=15 December 2011}} From the [[Geopolitics|geopolitical]] [[Point of view (philosophy)|point of view]], the war ended in the [[Breakup of East and West Pakistan|breaking-up of the unity]] of Pakistan from being the largest [[Muslim world|Muslim country]] in the world to its [[Stagflation in Pakistan|politico-economic]] and military collapse that resulted from a direct [[India and state-sponsored terrorism|foreign intervention]] in 1971.{{cite book|last1=Malik|first1=Anas|title=Political Survival in Pakistan: Beyond Ideology|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781136904196|url=https://books.google.com/?id=dLkuCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA50&q=world's%20largest%20islamic%20state%20west%20pakistan|accessdate=7 November 2016|language=en|date=2010-10-22}}{{rp|50}}{{cite book|last1=Humayun|first1=Arif|title=Connivance by Silence: How the Majority's Failure to Challenge Politically Motivated [Mis]interpretation of the Qur'an Empowered Radicals to Exploit Islam and Propagate Radicalism|publisher=Xlibris Corporation|isbn=9781453595725|url=https://books.google.com/?id=NxETqZTH390C&pg=PA47&q=world's%20largest%20islamic%20state%20%20pakistan%201971|language=en|date=2010-10-29}}{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=December 2017}}{{rp|47}}{{cite book|last1=Waines|first1=David|title=An Introduction to Islam|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521539067|url=https://books.google.com/?id=YYxZ0QpKBGsC&pg=PP15&q=world's%20largest%20islamic%20state%20%20pakistan%201971|accessdate=7 November 2016|language=en|date=2003-11-06}}{{rp|1}}{{cite book|last1=Dogra|first1=Wg Cdr C. Deepak|title=Pakistan: Caught in the Whirlwind|publisher=Lancer Publishers LLC|isbn=9781940988221|url=https://books.google.com/?id=3zooCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT223&q=world's%20largest%20islamic%20nation%20west%20pakistan|accessdate=7 November 2016|language=en|date=2015-12-09}}Further information relates in [[Hamoodur Rahman Commission]]. The Pakistani policy-making institutions further feared that the historicity of the [[Two-nation theory]] had been disproved by the war, that [[Muslim nationalism in South Asia|Muslim nationalism]] had proved insufficient to keep Bengalis a part of Pakistan. The [[Pakistani society|Pakistani people]] were not mentally prepared to accept the magnitude of this kind of defeat, as the [[Pakistan Television Corporation|state electronic media]] had been projecting imaginary victories; however, the [[News channels in Pakistan|privately-owned electronic news media]] coverage in East Pakistan had reported the complexity of the situation. When the ceasefire that came from the surrender of East Pakistan was finally announced, the people could not come to terms with the magnitude of defeat; spontaneous demonstrations and massive protests erupted on the streets of major [[Cities in Pakistan|metropolitan cities]] in Pakistan. According to Pakistani historians, the trauma was extremely severe, and the cost of the war for Pakistan in monetary terms and in human resources was very high.{{cite book|last1=Siddique|first1=Abubakar|title=The Pashtuns: The Unresolved Key to the Future of Pakistan and Afghanistan|publisher=Random House India|isbn=9788184006254|url=https://books.google.com/?id=4eb-AwAAQBAJ&pg=PT60&q=The%20trauma%20extremely%20severe%20in%20Pakistan%201971|accessdate=23 December 2016|language=en|date=2014-06-10}}{{rp|xxx}}Langewiesche, William (November 2005). "The Wrath of Khan". The Atlantic. Retrieved 31 July 2016. Demoralized and finding unable to control the situation, the Yahya administration fell when President Yahya Khan [[Turnover (employment)|turned over]] his presidency to [[Zulfiqar Ali Bhutto]], who was sworn in on 20 December 1971 as [[President of Pakistan|President]] [[Chief Martial Law Administrator|with the control of the military]].{{cite web|url=http://ghazali.net/book1/chapter_5.htm|title=Islamic Pakistan, The Second Martial Law|author =Abdus Sattar Ghazali|accessdate=20 October 2009}} The loss of East Pakistan shattered the prestige of the Pakistani military. Pakistan lost half its navy, a quarter of its air force, and a third of its army. The war also exposed the shortcomings of Pakistan's declared strategic doctrine that the "defence of East Pakistan lay in West Pakistan".{{cite web|url=http://www.defencejournal.com/2000/oct/yaqub.htm |title=Prince, Soldier, Statesman – Sahabzada Yaqub Khan |website=Defence Journal |accessdate=20 October 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090312092440/http://www.defencejournal.com/2000/oct/yaqub.htm |archivedate=12 March 2009 |df=dmy }} [[Hussain Haqqani]], in his book ''Pakistan: Between Mosque and Military'' notes, {{quote|Moreover, the army had failed to fulfill its promises of fighting to the last man. The eastern command had laid down arms after losing only 1,300 men in battle. In West Pakistan 1,200 military deaths had accompanied lackluster military performance.Ḥaqqānī, p. 87}} In his book ''The 1971 Indo-Pak War: A Soldier's Narrative'', Pakistan Army's [[Major general|Major General]] Hakeem Arshad Qureshi, a veteran of this conflict, noted: {{quote|We must accept the fact that, as a people, we had also contributed to the bifurcation of our own country. It was not a Niazi, or a Yahya, even a Mujib, or a Bhutto, or their key assistants, who alone were the cause of our break-up, but a corrupted system and a flawed social order that our own apathy had allowed to remain in place for years. At the most critical moment in our history we failed to check the limitless ambitions of individuals with dubious antecedents and to thwart their selfish and irresponsible behaviour. It was our collective 'conduct' that had provided the enemy an opportunity to dismember us.{{cite news |date=15 December 2002 |title=Excerpts: We never learn |url=http://www.dawn.com/weekly/books/archive/021215/books3.htm |newspaper=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]]}}{{dead link|date=July 2015}}{{cbignore}}}} The Indian Army Chief in 1971, Field Marshal Sam Manekshaw, had the highest respect for the fighting capability of the Pakistan Army, and he did not accept the theory that they did not fight the war with enough vigour and zeal.{{cite book|last=Lala|first=R. M.|title=A touch of greatness: encounters with the eminent|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GxduAAAAMAAJ|date=1 January 2001|publisher=Viking}} In a [[BBC]] interview, he said:
The Pakistan Army in East Pakistan fought very gallantly. But they had no chance. They were a thousand miles away from their base. I had eight or nine months to make my preparations. I had got a superiority of almost 15 to 1....[http://www.tribuneindia.com/1999/99aug02/head1.htm Indira feared coup from 'Sam'], The Tribune India, 1 August 1999.{{citation |last=KTInfotainmentTV |title=FTF Field Marshal Monekshaw 28 7 1999 |date=28 July 1999 |publication-date=17 October 2011 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L-tgRl_VK_Q |time=15:30}}{{cite book|author=Ahmad Faruqui|title=Rethinking the National Security of Pakistan: The Price of Strategic Myopia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ElHfAAAAMAAJ|year=2003|publisher=Ashgate|isbn=978-0-7546-1497-5|page=55|quote=Field Marshal Manekshaw, Chief of Staff of the Indian Army in 1971, paid them the ultimate compliment when he stated that: The Pakistan Army in East Pakistan fought very gallantly. But they had no chance. They were a thousand miles away from their base. And I had eight or nine months to make my preparations [while they were being worn out in a counter insurgency war against the secessionist forces of the Mukti Bahini]. I had a superiority of almost five-to-one.}}
However, independent defence sources stated that the Indian superiority was less than 2 to 1.[http://www.rediff.com/news/slide-show/slide-show-1-three-indian-blunders-in-the-1971-war/20111212.htm Three Indian blunders in the 1971 war], Rediff News, 12 December 2011. The United States Air Force's Brigadier-General Chuck Yeager, the [[World War II]] veteran and US flying ace who witnessed the war in 1971, is of the view that Pakistan did not lose the war, as India did not annex it.{{cite news|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/1179296/american-flying-ace-believes-pakistan-won-1971-war|title=American flying ace believes Pakistan won 1971 war|work=Express Tribune|date=9 September 2016|accessdate=10 September 2016}} After the war, the Pakistan Army's generals in the East held each other responsible for the atrocities committed, but most of the burden was laid on Lieutenant-General Tikka Khan, who earned notoriety from his actions as governor of the East; he was called the "Butcher of Bengal" because of the widespread atrocities committed within the areas of his responsibility.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/mar/30/local/me-passings30.1|title=Gen. Tikka Khan, 87; 'Butcher of Bengal' Led Pakistani Army|date=30 March 2002|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=11 April 2010}} Unlike his contemporary Yaqub who was a [[Pacifism|pacifist]] and knew well of the limits of force, Tikka was a "soldier known for his eager use of force" to settle his differences.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pkstnjPZkuQC&pg=PA100|title=Songs of Blood and Sword: A Daughter's Memoir|last1=Bhutto|first1=Fatima|date=2011-09-06|publisher=Nation Books|isbn=978-1-56858-712-7|page=100|author-link=Fatima Bhutto|accessdate=19 August 2016}}{{rp|100}}{{cite web|url=http://www.massviolence.org/Khan-1917-2002-General-Tikka|title=Khan (1917–2002), General Tikka|last=Baixas|first=Lionel|date=21 June 2008|publisher=Online Encyclopedia of Mass Violence|accessdate=17 July 2013}}{{cite journal|last=Alamgir|first=Aurangzaib|date=Nov–Dec 2012|title=Pakistan's Balochistan Problem: An Insurgency's Rebirth|url=http://www.worldaffairsjournal.org/article/pakistan%E2%80%99s-balochistan-problem-insurgency%E2%80%99s-rebirth|journal=World Affairs|access-date=17 July 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/2006/aug/29guest1.htm|title=Is Balochistan another Bangladesh?|author=Col (retd) Anil Athale|date=29 August 2006|newspaper=Rediff India Abroad|access-date=17 July 2013}} Confessing at the hearings of the [[Hamoodur Rahman Commission|War Enquiry Commission]], Lieutenant-General A.A.K. Niazi reportedly commented on Tikka's actions and noted: "On the night between 25/26 March 1971, [General] Tikka struck. Peaceful night was turned into a time of wailing, crying and burning. [General] Tikka let loose everything at his disposal as if raiding an enemy, not dealing with his own misguided and misled people. The military action was a display of stark cruelty more merciless than the massacres at [[Bukhara]] and [[Baghdad]] by [[Chengiz Khan]] and [[Hulagu Khan|Halaku Khan]]... [General] Tikka... resorted to the killing of civilians and a [[scorched earth]] policy. His orders to his troops were: "I want the land, not the people..."."{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=sabUQ7zKUvsC&pg=PA295&q=Peaceful%20night%20was%20turned%20into%20a%20time%20of%20wailing%2C%20crying%20and%20burning.%20%5BGeneral%5D%20Tikka%20let%20loose%20everything|title=Airborne to Chairborne: Memoirs of a War Veteran Aviator-lawyer of the Indian Air Force|last1=Ahluwalia|first1=A.|date=June 2012|publisher=Xlibris Corporation|isbn=9781469196565|language=en|accessdate=23 December 2016}}{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=December 2017}}{{rp|295}} [[Major-General]] [[Rao Farman Ali|Rao Farman]] reportedly had written in his table diary: "Green land of East Pakistan will be painted red. It was painted red by Bengali blood."{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=nYppZ_dEjdIC|title=Pakistan: between mosque and the military|last=Haqqani|first=Hussain|publisher=Carnegie Endowment|year=2005|isbn=978-0-87003-214-1|page=74|accessdate=11 April 2010}} However, Farman forcefully denied writing that comment, and laid all responsibility on Tikka, while testifying at the War Enquiry Commission in 1974.{{cite web|url=http://etongbtong.blogspot.com/2010/03/interview-of-major-general-rao-farman.html|title=অরূপকথা: Interview of Major General Rao Farman Ali AKA "The Butcher of Bengal"|last1=(arup)|first1=অরূপ|date=13 March 2010|website=অরূপকথা|publisher=অরূপকথা}} Major reforms were carried out by successive governments in Pakistan after the war in the light of many insightful recommendations made in the Hamoodur Rahman Commission's [[Hamoodur Rahman Commission Report|Report]].{{cite book|last1=Burki|first1=Shahid Javed|title=Pakistan Under Bhutto, 1971–1977|publisher=Springer|isbn=9781349195299|url=https://books.google.com/?id=LX6xCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA59&q=indian%20army%20vs%20west%20pakistan%20army%201971|language=en|date=1988-11-01}}{{rp|254}} To address the economic disparity, the [[National Finance Commission Award|NFC system]] was established to equally distribute the taxation revenue among the [[Four Provinces (Pakistan)|four provinces]], the large-scale [[Nationalisation in Pakistan|nationalization]] of industries and nationwide [[Census in Pakistan|census]] were carried out in 1972.{{cite web|last1=GoP|first1=Government of Pakistan|title=Population of Pakistan in 1972|url=http://www.pbs.gov.pk/sites/default/files/other/pocket_book2006/2.pdf|publisher=Bureau of Statistics|accessdate=24 December 2016}} The [[Constitution of Pakistan|Constitution]] was promulgated in 1973 that reflected this equal balance and a compromise between [[Islamism]] and [[Humanism]], and provided guaranteed equal human rights to all.{{cite web|last1=et. al.|title=Constitution of Pakistan|url=http://storyofpakistan.com/the-constitution-of-1973/|website=Story of Pakistan|publisher=Nazaria-e-Pakistan, Part IV|accessdate=2 June 2014}} The [[Pakistani military|military]] was heavily reconstructed and heavily reorganised, with President Bhutto appointing chiefs of staff in each inter-service, contrary to [[Commander-in-chief|C-in-Cs]], and making instruction on human rights compulsory in the military syllabus in each branch of inter-services.{{cite book|last1=Singh|first1=Ravi Shekhar Narain Singh|title=The Military Factor in Pakistan|publisher=Lancer Publishers|isbn=9780981537894|url=https://books.google.com/?id=wCm2DFZblOYC&pg=PA62&q=Bhutto%20appoints%20chiefs%20of%20staff%20of%20air%20army|accessdate=24 December 2016|language=en|year=2008}}{{rp|62–100}} Major investments were directed towards modernising the navy.{{rp|100}} The military's [[chain of command]] was centralized in [[Joint Staff Headquarters (Pakistan)|JS HQ]] led by an appointed [[Chairman Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee|Chairman joint chiefs committee]] to coordinate the combined and well-integrated military efforts to safeguard the nation's defence and unity.{{rp|62–63}} In addition, Pakistan sought to have a diversified foreign policy, as Pakistani geostrategists had been shocked that both China and the United States provided limited support to Pakistan during the course of the war, with the US displaying an inability to supply weapons that Pakistan needed the most.{{cite book|last1=Kapur|first1=Ashok|title=India and the South Asian Strategic Triangle|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781136902611|url=https://books.google.com/?id=iALGBQAAQBAJ&pg=PT257&q=Pakistani%20generals%20surprised%20by%20Chinese%201971|accessdate=26 December 2016|language=en|date=2010-12-14}}{{rp|xxxiii}} On January 20, 1972, Pakistan under Bhutto launched the [[Pakistan and its Nuclear Deterrent Program|clandestine development]] of [[nuclear weapons]] in a view of "never to allow another foreign invasion of Pakistan."{{cite book|last1=Paul|first1=T. V.|last2=Studies|first2=Teleglobe Raoul-Dandurand Chair of Strategic and Diplomatic|last3=sécurité|first3=Université du Québec à Montréal Centre d'études des politiques étrangères et de|title=Power Versus Prudence: Why Nations Forgo Nuclear Weapons|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press – MQUP|isbn=9780773520875|url=https://books.google.com/?id=XCm0JSs27eAC&pg=PA133&q=Pakistan%201971%20war%20nuclear|accessdate=24 December 2016|language=en|year=2000}}{{rp|133–135}} This crash program reached parity in 1977 when the first [[nuclear weapon design|weapon design]] was successfully achieved.{{cite web|title=Pakistan's Nuclear Weapons Program – The Beginning|url=http://nuclearweaponarchive.org/Pakistan/PakOrigin.html|website=nuclearweaponarchive.org|accessdate=24 December 2016}} === Bangladesh === {{main|1971 East Pakistan genocide}} As a result of the war, East Pakistan disintegrated and became an independent country, [[Bangladesh]], as the world's fourth most populous Muslim state on 16 December 1971.{{rp|xxxv}} Pakistan itself secured the release of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman from the [[Headquarter Jail|Headquarter Prison]] and allowed him to return to Dacca. On 19 January 1972, Mujib was inaugurated as the first [[President of Bangladesh]], later becoming the [[Prime Minister of Bangladesh]] in 1974.{{rp|xxxv}} On the brink of defeat in around 14 December 1971, the media reports indicated that the Pakistan Army soldiers, the local [[East Pakistan Police]] they controlled, [[Razakar (East Pakistan)|''razakars'']] and the [[East Pakistan Central Peace Committee|''Shanti Committee'']] carried out [[1971 East Pakistan Intellectuals massacre|systematic killings]] of professionals such as physicians, teachers, and other intellectuals,{{cite news|title=125 Slain in Dacca Area, Believed Elite of Bengal|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1971/12/19/archives/125-slain-in-dacca-area-believed-elite-of-bengal-125-found-slain.html|work=The New York Times|location=New York, NY, USA|page=1|date=19 December 1971|accessdate=4 January 2008|quote=At least 125 persons, believed to be physicians, professors, writers and teachers, were found murdered today in a field outside Dacca. All the victims' hands were tied behind their backs and they had been bayoneted, garroted or shot.
