He is Emeritus Professor of History and retired from the Historical Studies department at the [[University of Cape Town]], South Africa in 2016. He was previously Research Fellow at [[Clare Hall, Cambridge|Clare Hall]], [[University of Cambridge]] and Lecturer in [[Commonwealth]] History at the [[University of Edinburgh]]. He holds MA and PhD degrees in History from the University of Cambridge and BA degrees in [[Art History]] and [[Linguistics]] from the [[University of South Africa]].<ref>[http://www.goodreads.com/author/show/271853.Nigel_Worden Good Reads Profile]. Retrieved 26 April 2010.</ref><ref>[http://www.indianoceanworldcentre.com/people/worden.php Nigel Worden's Profile] at the IOWC website.</ref>
==Publications==
Publications by Nigel Worden include:<ref>[http://web.uct.ac.za/depts/history/worden.htm Nigel Worden's Profile] at the [[University of Cape Town]] History Department Website. Retrieved 26 April 2010.</ref>
* ''Slavery in Dutch South Africa'' Cambridge, [[Cambridge University Press]], 1985 reprinted 2010) * "The slaves, 1652–1834" in R. Elphick and H. Giliomee (eds) ''The shaping of South African society, 1652–1840'' (2nd ed. Maskew Miller Longman, 1989, reprinted 1990, 1991, translated into Afrikaans 1991) [jointly with James Armstrong] * ''Breaking the Chains: Slavery and Emancipation in the nineteenth century Cape Colony''. Jointly edited with [[Clifton Crais]] (Witwatersrand University Press, 1994) * "Contested heritage at the Cape Town Waterfront", ''International Journal of Heritage Studies'', 2 (1996) * ''The Making of Modern South Africa, Conquest, Segregation and Apartheid''. (Oxford, [[Wiley-Blackwell|Blackwell]], first published 1994, 4th edition 2007) * "Contested heritage in a South African city: Cape Town" in B. Shaw and R. Jones (eds), ''Contested Urban Heritage: Voices from the Periphery'' (Aldershot, Ashgate Publishers, 1997). * ''Cape Town: The Making of a City. An illustrated history''. N. Worden, E. van Heyningen, V. Bickford-Smith (Cape Town, David Philip, 1998) {{ISBN|978-0-86486-435-2}} * "Commemorating, invoking and suppressing Cape slavery" with [[Kerry Ward]] in Sarah Nuttall and Carli Coetzee (eds) ''The Making of Memory in South Africa''. Cape Town, [[Oxford University Press]], 1998) * "National identity and heritage tourism in Melaka", ''Indonesia and Malay World'' 31, 31–43. * ''Trials of slavery: selected documents concerning slaves from the criminal records of the Council of Justice at the Cape of Good Hope, 1705–1794'', edited jointly with [[Gerald Groenewald]], [[Van Riebeeck Society]], Cape Town, 2005. * "Artisan conflicts in a colonial context: the Cape Town blacksmith strike of 1752", ''Labor History'' 46:2 (May 2005), 155–184. * "New approaches to VOC history in South Africa", ''South African Historical Journal'' 59 (2007), 3–18. * "Strangers ashore: sailor identity and social conflict in mid-18th century Cape Town", ''Kronos'' 33 (2007), 72–83. * {{"'}}Below the line the devil reigns': death and dissent aboard a VOC vessel", ''South African Historical Journal'' 61:4 (2009), 701–29. * "Demanding satisfaction: violence, masculinity and honour in late eighteenth-century Cape Town", ''Kronos'' 35 (2009), 32–47. * "The changing politics of slave heritage in the Western Cape, South Africa", ''Journal of African History'' 50 (2009), 23–40.
==Awards==
He has received the following awards:<ref>[http://www.indianoceanworldcentre.com/people/worden.php Awards received by Nigel Worden] – Profile at the IOWC website. Retrieved 26 April 2010.</ref>
* G. Wesley Johnson Award from the U.S Council on Public History for the best article in the field of public history published in 1994 (1995) * Meritorious publication award, UCT for [[Cape Town]]: the Making of a City (2000) * Overseas Visiting Fellowship, [[St John's College, Cambridge|St. John's College]], Cambridge (2002); * [[Nelson Mandela]] Chair in Humanities grant to edit volume of slave court testimonies to be published by the Van Riebeeck Society (2003–04) * Western Cape Provincial Honours: Premier's Commendation for contributions to the study of slavery (2005)

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Update|inaccurate=yes|date=August 2016}} [[File:Fleet 5 nations.jpg|thumb|right|A not unusual five-country NATO multinational fleet (namely the United States, the United Kingdom, Italy, France, and the Netherlands) during ''[[Operation Enduring Freedom]]'' in the Oman Sea. In four descending columns, from left to right: [[Maestrale class frigate|MM ''Maestrale'']] (F 570), [[French frigate De Grasse (D 612)|FS ''De Grasse'']] (D 612); [[USS John C. Stennis|USS ''John C. Stennis'']] (CVN 74), [[French aircraft carrier Charles de Gaulle (R91)|FS ''Charles De Gaulle'']] (R 91), [[French frigate Surcouf (F711)|FS ''Surcouf'']] (F 711); [[USS Port Royal (CG-73)|USS ''Port Royal'']] (CG-73), [[HMS Ocean (L12)|HMS ''Ocean'']] (L 12), [[USS John F. Kennedy (CV 67)|USS ''John F. Kennedy'']] (CV 67), [[Hr. Ms. Van Amstel|HNLMS ''Van Amstel'']] (F 831); and [[Durand De la Penne class destroyer|MM ''Durand de la Penne'']] (D 560).]]
Following the [[terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001]], several nations took on [[Al-Qaeda]] and the [[Taliban]] during [[Operation Enduring Freedom]] (OEF) in [[Afghanistan]]. OEF was the initial combat operations starting on 7 October 2001, in the wake of the [[11 September attacks]] on the United States, and during 2002 and 2003.
This list covers US and coalition forces and other forms of support for OEF from October 2001. Some nations' operations in Afghanistan continued as part of NATO's [[International Security Assistance Force]] (ISAF). For example, United States troops are deployed both in the OEF and ISAF.
''See the article [[Afghanistan War order of battle]] for the current disposition of coalition forces in Afghanistan.''
''For coalition forces involved in NATO International Security Assistance Force (ISAF) combat operations in southern Afghanistan in 2006, see the article [[Coalition combat operations in Afghanistan in 2006]]. For coalition forces in Afghanistan in 2007, see the article [[Coalition combat operations in Afghanistan in 2007]]. For coalition forces in Afghanistan in 2008, see the article [[Coalition combat operations in Afghanistan in 2008]]. For the [[International Security Assistance Force]] for coalition forces in Afghanistan as part of ISAF.''{{refn|Primary sources [[United States Department of Defense|U.S. Department of Defense]] [http://www.defenselink.mil/news/May2002/d20020523cu.pdf] and US [[State Department]] [https://fpc.state.gov/documents/organization/6207.pdf].|group=Note}}
==Afghanistan== [[Afghan National Security Forces]] (ANSF) are currently trying to take an increasing role in battling the [[Taliban insurgency]].
==Albania== Between 2003 and 2013 Albania deployed a total of 2944 troops to Afghanistan with members of the [[Special Operations Battalion (Albania)]] operating in various mission across the provinces of Kandahar and Herat.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mod.gov.al/arkiv/eng/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=899:afganistan&catid=103&Itemid=667|title=Afghanistan, ISAF Operations led by NATO|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180620002228/http://www.mod.gov.al/arkiv/eng/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=899:afganistan&catid=103&Itemid=667#|archive-date=20 June 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Australia== At their peak Australian troops in Afghanistan numbered 1,550. They were one of only three countries to openly support operations in Afghanistan at the war's beginning, along with the United States and the United Kingdom. Australian troops were deployed to Uruzgan province, while Special Forces personnel also operated in Afghanistan.
==Armenia== The [[Armed Forces of Armenia]] is tripling its Afghan contingent to 130 personnel and it may increase its military presence in Afghanistan to 260 personnel at the next troop rotation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurasianet.org/node/63466|title=Think the Afghanistan War Is Over? Armenia Doesn't|work=EurasiaNet.org|accessdate=26 December 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141227013928/http://www.eurasianet.org/node/63466#|archive-date=27 December 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Azerbaijan== The [[Azerbaijani Armed Forces]] has deployed over 184 soldiers to Afghanistan.
==Bangladesh== Bangladesh provided the use of its airspace and seaports.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XLvU9lroRuUC&pg=PA662&lpg=PA662&dq=2002+bangladesh+airspace+us+forces+afghanistan&source=bl&ots=FJTCXA5fGe&sig=mrPIV6Itc4dzQxV7y3_4LYyHbNk&hl=bn&sa=X&ei=VjmBVJ2eE4K3uQT_vYFY&ved=0CCwQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=2002%20bangladesh%20airspace%20us%20forces%20afghanistan&f=false|title=The Europa World Year Book 2003|publisher=|accessdate=26 December 2014}}</ref>
==Bulgaria== Bulgaria has deployed 608 troops in Afghanistan, as well as medical personnel.
==Belgium== In 2002, a tri-national detachment known as the European Participating Air Forces of 18 Danish, Netherlands and Norwegian [[F-16]] ground attack fighters aircraft deployed to [[Manas Air Base]] in Kyrgyzstan to support operations in Afghanistan{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}}. Belgium contributed a [[C-130 Hercules]] and four F-16 aircraft.{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}} Currently Belgium has around 550 troops stationed in Afghanistan, mainly in Kabul, Kunduz and Kandahar airport.{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}}
==Bosnia and Herzegovina== Bosnia and Herzegovina deployed a unit of 37 men to destroy munitions and clear mines, in addition to 6 command personnel, as part of the Multinational force in Iraq. The unit was first deployed to Fallujah, then Talil Air Base, and is now located at Camp Echo. In December 2006, the Bosnian government formally extended its mandate through June 2007. Bosnia and Herzegovina is planning to send another 49 soldiers from the 6th infantry division to Iraq in August 2008, their mission will be to protect/guard Camp Victory in Baghdad.
==Canada== {{Main|Canada's role in the invasion of Afghanistan|Canadian Forces casualties in Afghanistan}} In 2002, Canada had 2,100 personnel in the [[CENTCOM]] region (1,100 land, 225 air (6 aircraft) and 700 naval personnel (3 ships)){{Citation needed|date=May 2009}}. Ground troops included elements of the [[Princess Patricia's Canadian Light Infantry]] Regiment and [[Royal Canadian Regiment]], and [[JTF2]] special forces{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}}. Since initial deployments supporting OEF, Canadian forces have supported OEF and ISAF. Since the summer of 2006, the expanded Canadian force supported the NATO ISAF mission in south Afghanistan.
Exit strategy: Canada had pledged to stop its military operations there by the end of 2014.<ref name="ctv.ca">{{cite web|url=http://www.forces.gc.ca/en/operations-abroad-past/afg-timeline.page|title=Archived copy|access-date=17 September 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180405145921/http://www.forces.gc.ca/en/operations-abroad-past/afg-timeline.page#|archive-date=5 April 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> And had begun logistical preparations to end any substantive combat role by the end of 2011<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/forces-prepare-for-afghan-withdrawal/article1353242/|title=Forces prepare for Afghan withdrawal|work=The Globe and Mail|accessdate=26 December 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141227022442/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/forces-prepare-for-afghan-withdrawal/article1353242/#|archive-date=27 December 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==People's Republic of China== The [[People's Republic of China]] has provided mine-clearance and police training for Afghan Security Forces, but has resisted international pressure to deploy troops to the country. The Chinese government considers Afghanistan a quagmire, and fears that if troops were to be deployed, rising casualties would provoke massive antiwar sentiment in China, due to the [[One Child Policy]].<ref>[[Newsweek]]: 21 November 2009 Issue</ref>
==Republic of the Congo== The Republic of the Congo offered the United States and allies logistical support.{{Citation needed|date=May 2009}}{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}}
==Cyprus== Cyprus offered the United States and allies use of its airspace and airports. Also, the United Kingdom used its RAF bases in their Sovereign Base Areas in Atrokiri and Dhekelia to stage attacks and aid the ground forces.
==Czech Republic== Since April 2007, a 35-man deployment of the Czech Military Police's Special Operations Group was deployed to Helmand Province to support British forces under ISAF command in a variety of force protection and Direct Action tasks. In 2011, The Czech deployment was increased with a full deployment of a Special Operations Task Group, including the [[601st Special Forces Group]] under the newly formed ISAF SOF (Special Operations Forces) Command.<ref name=Neville>Neville, Leigh, '' Special Forces in the War on Terror (General Military)'', Osprey Publishing, 2015 {{ISBN|978-1-4728-0790-8}}, p.141</ref>
Provided training and material support for allied Afghan forces (donation of Mi-17 and Mi-24 helicopters to ANA). Sent 3 times a Special Forces Detachment (601st Special Forces Group). Other activities in ISAF – field hospital, KAIA airfield command, [[PRT Logar]], force protection for German PRT and Dutch PRT.
==Denmark== Since 2002 the number of ground forces committed by the Danish army has been steadily increased from 50 to 750 soldiers and support staff. These forces include a tank platoon with 3 [[Leopard 2]] model 2A5DK tanks. The majority of the Danish forces are deployed in the [[Helmand Province]] operating in the [[Gerishk District]] as part of the [[International Security Assistance Force|ISAF]] force under UK command. The Danish forces have suffered substantial casualties including 43 deaths up till January, 2013. This is currently the highest level of casualties compared to the contribution size.
Additionally Danish [[Jægerkorpset]] special forces have been deployed at various times – including a substantial number in 2002.
In 2002, a tri-national detachment known as the European Participating Air Forces of 18 Danish, Netherlands and Norwegian F-16 ground attack/fighter aircraft deployed to Manas in Kyrgyzstan to support operations in Afghanistan. Denmark contributed 6 F-16 aircraft.
Lars Løkke Rasmussen, prime minister of Denmark (2009-2011), said his country's commitment depends on whether Afghanistan's 7 Nov. presidential runoff produces a credible leader (the run off was cancelled).<ref name="ctv.ca"/>
==Egypt== Egyptian Field Hospital at Bagram: Egypt opened an Egyptian Field Hospital at Bagram in 2003. The hospital treats more than 7,000 Afghans per month. Treatment is provided free of charge. 31 percent of the hospital's patients are children.
link: [[Egyptian Field Hospital at Bagram]] Also, Egypt offered the use of its airspace.
==Estonia== Estonia offered the use of its airspace and provided logistical support in theatre. Estonia deployed about 150, and later a further 250, to Afghanistan.<ref>[http://www.afghanconflictmonitor.org/2007/12/estonia-extends.html Estonia Extends Afghan Mission Through 2008] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071231075451/http://www.afghanconflictmonitor.org/2007/12/estonia-extends.html |date=31 December 2007 }}</ref>
==France== Over 4,000 personnel including the [[Marine Nationale]] (one [[CVBG]], comprising the ''[[French aircraft carrier Charles de Gaulle (R91)|Charles de Gaulle]]'', frigates ''[[French frigate Lamotte-Picquet (D645)|La Motte-Picquet]]'', ''[[French frigate Jean de Vienne (D643)|Jean de Vienne]]'' and ''[[French frigate Jean Bart (D615)|Jean Bart]]'', the [[nuclear submarine|nuclear attack submarine]] ''[[French submarine Rubis (S601)|Rubis]]'', the tanker ''[[Durance class ships|Meuse]]'' and the [[aviso]] ''[[D'Estienne d'Orves class|Commandant Ducuing]]'') 3,200 ground troops and 350 from the [[Armée de l'Air]] (12 [[Mirage 2000]], [[Mirage F1]] and [[Mirage IV]] ground-attack and [[reconnaissance aircraft]]). The first deployed French force was composed of soldiers from the 21st Marine Infantry Regiment deployed on 17 November 2001, to [[Mazar-e Sharif]].
French special forces operators have served in Afghanistan since the formation of ISAF, in 2003 150 [[Special Operations Command (France)|COS]] operators were deployed to replace the Italian ISAF contingent, the COS primarily conducted reconnaissance and close-protection tasks.<ref name=Neville>Neville, Leigh, '' Special Forces in the War on Terror (General Military)'', Osprey Publishing, 2015 {{ISBN|978-1-4728-0790-8}}, p.141</ref> In 2001 and beginning again in the summer of 2003, 200 soldiers from various units of the [[Army Special Forces Brigade]] (BFST), along with marine and air commandos, have conducted operations against the Taliban, under command and in co-operation with U.S. special operations forces present in the area. French forces have since supported the ISAF mission.
Between 2003 and 2007, a 200-man COS unit operated under direct ISAF SOF command of OEF-A, their tasks were restricted to what author Stephen Saideman said was "short-term counter terrorism and counterinsurgency raids" rather than londer Special Reconnaissance missions, nor were they allowed to conduct partnered operations. Despite the restrictions, French SOF operators were carried out a large number of successful Direct Action operations, often in joint operations with American and sometimes British special forces. The French special forces contribution to OEF-A ended in 2007 after disputes over its role.<ref name=Neville>Neville, Leigh, '' Special Forces in the War on Terror (General Military)'', Osprey Publishing, 2015 {{ISBN|978-1-4728-0790-8}}, p.141</ref>
In August 2008, France took over control of the Kabul regional command. Ten French troops were killed and a further 21 wounded in an attack – the heaviest loss of troops France has suffered since deploying to Afghanistan in 2002 – it was announced on 19 August.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/south_asia/7569942.stm|title=BBC NEWS - South Asia - Afghan ambush kills French troops|publisher=|accessdate=26 December 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170812104155/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/south_asia/7569942.stm#|archive-date=12 August 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In 2009, a 150-man French special forces task group deployed operating directly for the French ISAF contribution and also conducted significant mentoring of Afghan security forces.<ref name=Neville>Neville, Leigh, '' Special Forces in the War on Terror (General Military)'', Osprey Publishing, 2015 {{ISBN|978-1-4728-0790-8}}, p.141</ref> As of 17 September 2011, 75 French soldiers have died.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://icasualties.org/oef/Nationality.aspx?hndQry=France# |title=French lost on icasulaties.org |access-date=18 September 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720203839/http://icasualties.org/OEF/Nationality.aspx?hndQry=France# |archive-date=20 July 2011 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> All French forces left Afghanistan in 2012.<ref name=Neville>Neville, Leigh, '' Special Forces in the War on Terror (General Military)'', Osprey Publishing, 2015 {{ISBN|978-1-4728-0790-8}}, p.141</ref>
==Georgia== {{see|Role of Georgia in the War in Afghanistan (2001–14)}} Georgia deployed 174 troops to Afghanistan, and deployed 1,900 peacekeepers in 2010 for peacekeeping and counter-terrorism operations.
A total of 750–800 soldiers are being deployed since 2010, making Georgia the highest net contributor per capita to the coalition forces.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/n.php?n=georgia-deploying-750-soldiers-to-afghanistan-2010-04-08|title=Georgia deploying 750 soldiers to Afghanistan|department=Horizons Hr-Kura-Aras|newspaper=Hurriyet Daily News|archiveurl=https://archive.today/20130125232357/http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/default.aspx?pageid=438&n=georgia-deploying-750-soldiers-to-afghanistan-2010-04-08|archivedate=25 January 2013|via=Agence France-Presse|location=Tbilisi, Georiga|date=8 April 2010|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703523504574604242490533738|title=Mikheil Saakashvili: Georgia and the War in Afghanista|author=Mikheil Saakashvili|date=19 December 2009|work=Wall Street Journal|accessdate=26 December 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141227081238/http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703523504574604242490533738#|archive-date=27 December 2014|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Germany== In 2002, Germany had 2,560 personnel in the region. German [[Kommando Spezialkräfte]] (KSK) special forces were involved in combat operations. The German Navy has had three Frigates, one Fast Patrol Boat Group (five units) and four supply ships operating out of [[Djibouti]], in the [[Gulf of Aden]]. A German [[Airbus A310]] aircraft was on alert in Germany for use as a medevac platform. German forces have since supported the ISAF mission.
Although nominally under OEF command, the [[Kommando Spezialkräfte|KSK]] worked under ISAF command since 2005, carrying out numerous operations in the vicinity of the German deployment in Kabul, including a successful raid on an al-Qaeda safehouse for suicide bombers in October 2006. [[GSG9]] is also deployed to the Kabul area, providing specialist close protection to German officials and facilities. KSK operators have commented in the German media about the restrictions placed on them by their national caveats and stated that a preference for working directly for the Americans as part of OEF-A as they had done as part of [[Task Force K-Bar]].<ref name=Neville>Neville, Leigh, '' Special Forces in the War on Terror (General Military)'', Osprey Publishing, 2015 {{ISBN|978-1-4728-0790-8}}, p.142</ref>
The [[Bundestag]] is scheduled to vote on the mission in December 2009. It is claimed that other European nations will follow Germany's lead.<ref name="ctv.ca"/>
==Greece== Greek naval vessels have supported the ISAF since 2002.
==Hungary== Hungary deployed 360 troops to Afghanistan, provided training for allied forces, and opened its airbases for Allied use.
==India== India had offered all operational assistance to the United States, including use of its facilities, in any operations launched in pursuit of the perpetrators of the 11 September attack. Importantly Indian intelligence officials provided the United States with needed information concerning the financing and training of Islamic extremist groups in Afghanistan and Pakistan. The Indian government had also offered the United States the use of its territory for staging any military operations in Afghanistan.
On the naval front, India provided a frigate for escorting coalition shipping through the Straits of Malacca, made shipyards available for coalition ship repairs and opened ports for naval port calls. India offered the US its air bases and provided the Northern Alliance with logistical support. The Indian Army opened a hospital in Tajikistan, to treat injured Northern Alliance soldiers. India also loaned Mi-17 helicopters to the Northern Alliance.
==Iran== Iran, having viewed the Taliban as a bitter enemy, aided coalition forces in an uprising in [[Herat]].
==Ireland== Ireland has permitted U.S. military aircraft to use [[Shannon Airport]] as a refuelling hub. Also, Ireland has seven troops deployed to the Isaf's headquarters in Kabul.
==Italy== [[File:020201-N-6626D-003.jpg|Aircraft Carrier Giusppe Garibaldi|thumb|right|The Italian aircraft carrier ''[[Giuseppe Garibaldi (551)|Giuseppe Garibaldi]]'' and French aircraft carrier ''[[Charles de Gaulle (R 91)|Charles de Gaulle]]'' seen from the [[USS Theodore Roosevelt (CVN-71)|USS ''Theodore Roosevelt'']] (1 February 2002)]]
Italy deployed [[9th Paratroopers Assault Regiment|Col Moschin]] and [[List of military special forces units#Italy|Gruppo Operativo Incursori (GOI)]] to Afghanistan, Italian Special Operations Forces were not under US-led OEF-A command, instead it operated directly in support of the Italian ISAF Task force-Nibbio, where they carried out local force protection and reconnaissance tasks.<ref name=Neville>Neville, Leigh, '' Special Forces in the War on Terror (General Military)'', Osprey Publishing, 2015 {{ISBN|978-1-4728-0790-8}}, p.142</ref>
Italy had 2,850 men in Afghanistan.
Italian naval warships including its only [[Carrier Battle Group]] (with the aircraft carrier ''[[Giuseppe Garibaldi (551)|Giuseppe Garibaldi]]'') supported combat operations in the North Arabian Sea. Italy deployed a 43-man engineer team to [[Bagram]], Afghanistan to repair the runway in May 2002.
==Japan== Japan provided logistical support on coalition forces and financial, reconstruction and development support.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natolive/news_72931.htm?selectedLocale=en# |title=Japan: a valued partner in Afghanistan |access-date=14 March 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160314224325/http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natolive/news_72931.htm?selectedLocale=en# |archive-date=14 March 2016 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Kuwait== Kuwait provided basing and overflight permissions for all U.S. and coalition forces.
==Kyrgyzstan== Kyrgyzstan allowed US and allied aircraft to use [[Manas Air Base]].
==Latvia== Provided logistical support.
==Lithuania== 40 Special Forces AITVARAS troops, from November 2002 to 2004. After 2005 Lithuania has deployed up to 268 soldiers. Most of them were deployed in PRT Chaghcharan.
Lithuanian special forces were involved in Special Reconnaissance missions, since 2006 they have been in action in southern Afghanistan with British forces.<ref name=Neville>Neville, Leigh, '' Special Forces in the War on Terror (General Military)'', Osprey Publishing, 2015 {{ISBN|978-1-4728-0790-8}}, p.143</ref>
==Macedonia== Macedonia has 244 troops in Afghanistan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2010/sep/3/a-place-at-the-table-for-macedonia/|title=MIKO: A place at the table for Macedonia|work=The Washingtion Times|accessdate=26 December 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150101110250/http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2010/sep/3/a-place-at-the-table-for-macedonia/#|archive-date=1 January 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Malaysia== Malaysia provided use of its airspace and logistical support.
==Montenegro== Montenegro was scheduled to deploy 40 soldiers, a three-member medical team, and two officers under German command to Afghanistan in 2010.
==Netherlands== The Netherlands deployed 165 [[Korps Commandotroepen|KCT]] operators backed up by 4 Dutch Chinooks in 2005 under the direct command of OEF-A. In 2006 under ISAF mandate, the KCT deployed to [[Tarinkot]] in [[Uruzgan Province]] to work alongside Australian forces, the KCT conducted long-range reconnaissance and specialist intelligence gathering for both the Dutch Battle Group and ISAF SOF command.<ref name=Neville>Neville, Leigh, '' Special Forces in the War on Terror (General Military)'', Osprey Publishing, 2015 {{ISBN|978-1-4728-0790-8}}, p.143-144</ref>
The Netherlands help in 2006 included a build, fight and air support mission in Afghanistan with 2100 soldiers. In 2010 all Netherlands troops returned home and a few months later they began a police training mission with the Marechaussee and the Task Force. The Netherlands troops are members of the ISAF.
==New Zealand== [[Image:HMNZS Te Mana (F111) alongside USS Abraham Lincoln (CVN 72), 30 July, 2008.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Royal New Zealand Navy]] frigate [[HMNZS Te Mana (F111)|HMNZS ''Te Mana'']] operates as part of [[Combined Task Force 150|Task Force 150]] in the north [[Arabian Sea]]]] [[Prime Minister of New Zealand|New Zealand Prime Minister]] [[Helen Clark]] announced in April 2008 that there would be [http://www.nzherald.co.nz/section/1/story.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10502058 additional New Zealand troops] sent to the Provincial Reconstruction Team (PRT) in Banyan Province, because of concern over the deteriorating situation in Afghanistan. A member of the [[NZSAS]] in Afghanistan, Corporal [[Bill Apiata]], was awarded the [[Victoria Cross for New Zealand]] in 2007 for bravery under fire in 2004. Three other SAS soldiers also received bravery awards for actions during the same mission; two received the [[New Zealand Gallantry Decoration]] and one the [[New Zealand Gallantry Medal]]. There are also two C-130 Hercules and one [[Boeing 757]] transport aircraft and an unstated number (about 120) of [[New Zealand Special Air Service]] special forces soldiers and 2 [[ANZAC class frigate]]s in the [[Persian Gulf]].
In November 2007, a nephew of New Zealand's [[Minister of Defence (New Zealand)|Minister of Defence]] [[Phil Goff]] died in Afghanistan;<ref>[http://www.nzherald.co.nz/section/2/story.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=10477432]</ref> he was United States Army Captain Matthew Ferrara, who held both American and New Zealand citizenship. In July 2008, the sixth Australian soldier died in Afghanistan, New Zealand-born SAS Signaller Sean McCarthy.<ref>[http://www.nzherald.co.nz/section/1/story.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10520835]</ref>
The decision was made in August 2009 that NZSAS troops would be sent back to Afghanistan.
Exit strategy: The Government of New Zealand is working on an exit plan to pull all New Zealand troops out of Afghanistan.<ref name="Stuff.co.nz_3063692">{{cite news |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/3063692/Afghan-exit-plan-for-NZ-troops |title=Afghan exit plan for NZ troops |author=Reid, Neil |date=15 November 2009 |work=[[Sunday News (New Zealand)|Sunday News]] |accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref>
==Norway== Norwegian SOF, commanded by ISAF, has been in Afghanistan since 2001.<ref name=Neville>Neville, Leigh, '' Special Forces in the War on Terror (General Military)'', Osprey Publishing, 2015 {{ISBN|978-1-4728-0790-8}}, p.144</ref>
In 2002, a tri-national detachment known as the European Participating Air Forces of 18 Danish, Dutch and Norwegian F-16 ground attack fighters aircraft was deployed to Manas International Airport in Kyrgyzstan to support operations in Afghanistan. Norway contributed four to six F-16s. Also deployed from Norway were logistic teams, mine clearance teams, special forces groups (from [[Hærens Jegerkommando|HJK]] and [[Marinejegerkommandoen|MJK]]) and several C-130 transport aircraft.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mil.no/start/aktuelt/nyheter/article.jhtml?articleID=47596|title=Front page - Mil.no|publisher=|accessdate=26 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080213161228/http://www.mil.no/start/aktuelt/nyheter/article.jhtml?articleID=47596|archivedate=13 February 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Norway also has an army training base located in Afghanistan. Currently, they have lost one soldier in an [[Rocket propelled grenade|RPG]] attack and one special forces lieutenant in a shoot-out with hostile gunmen.<ref>Aftenposten Newspaper: [http://www.aftenposten.no/english/local/article795815.ece Taliban threaten more attacks in Afghanistan] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041228060325/http://www.aftenposten.no/english/local/article795815.ece |date=28 December 2004 }} {{en icon}}</ref><ref>Aftenposten Newspaper: [http://www.aftenposten.no/english/local/article1906015.ece "Fallen soldier comes home"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071018213537/http://www.aftenposten.no/english/local/article1906015.ece |date=18 October 2007 }} {{en icon}}</ref> Norway has also lost six soldiers in bomb attacks, including four [[Kystjegerkommandoen|KJKs]] in the same attack. Norway redeployed F-16 ground attack aircraft in 2006 as part of a joint Dutch-Norwegian unit supporting expanded NATO operations in Afghanistan.<ref>[http://www.mindef.nl/en/news/2006/1/20060125_news.aspx 13 February 2006: Dutch-Norwegian cooperation in Kabul – Netherlands MoD] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080527100040/http://www.mindef.nl/en/news/2006/1/20060125_news.aspx |date=27 May 2008 }}</ref> Currently Norway has a little more than 500 soldiers stationed in Afghanistan, mainly in the North and in [[Kabul]].
==Oman== Oman offered the United States and allies use of its airspace and air bases.
==Pakistan== Pakistan has been helping in the war against the Taliban.{{Citation needed|date=December 2012}} Pakistan and Iran agreed to open borders to receive the expected increased migration of [[Afghan refugees|refugees]] from Afghanistan. Earlier, Pakistan had supported the Taliban, especially during the 1996–1998 period when they were establishing control – later relations between the two were not as close. After the 9/11 attacks, Pakistan allocated three airbases to the United States for the invasion of Afghanistan. USA depends on Pakistan for a route to Afghanistan to supply the ISAF forces more than any source.
==Poland== A 40-man [[JW GROM]] element deployed to Afghanistan in early 2002, in 2007 both Grom and [[JW Komandosów]] were deployed to Kandahar (after earlier successful tours of Iraq operating alongside US Navy SEALs) under direct US Command. They weren't restricted by any national caveats-the only restriction placed on them was regarding cross-border operations into Pakistan. Along with Direct Action successes, they were considered very effective in training and mentoring Afghan National Police units.<ref name=Neville>Neville, Leigh, '' Special Forces in the War on Terror (General Military)'', Osprey Publishing, 2015 {{ISBN|978-1-4728-0790-8}}, p.144-145</ref>
Poland has approximately 2,500 troops, mainly from [[Polish Land Forces|Wojska Lądowe]], and 10 helicopters stationed primarily in Ghazni province. There is also [[Polish Special Forces|Wojska Specjalne]] compound: JW Grom (ISAF SOF TF-49), JW Komandosów (ISAF SOF TF-50) (Ghazni prov. Paktika prov.), JW Nil & HHD. Poland has also provided combat engineers and logistical support.
==Portugal== Portugal deployed 145 soldiers to Afghanistan, and provided a detachment of [[C-130 Hercules]] cargo planes. As a NATO member, Portugal supported the invocation of Article V.
==Qatar== Qatar offered the United States and allies use of the Al Udeid Airbase.
==Romania== 40 operators from the 1st Special Operations Battalion "Eagles" were deployed to Afghanistan in 2006 under the direct command of OEF-A, they transitioned to ISAF command the following year and were heavily involved in mentoring Afghan National Army units. The Romanian commitment eventually grew to a full Special Operations Task Group comprising three [[Special Forces (United States Army)#ODA|ODA (Operational Detachment Alphas)]]-sized elements. They often operating closely with [[US Army Special Forces]] ODAs on joint patrols and mixed ODAs of American and Romanian operators.<ref name=Neville>Neville, Leigh, '' Special Forces in the War on Terror (General Military)'', Osprey Publishing, 2015 {{ISBN|978-1-4728-0790-8}}, p.144</ref>
1,843 Force consists of a battalion in Qalat, Zabul Province. Additionally, a special forces squad (39 personnel) operates from Tagab in Kapisa Province, and a training detachment of 47 personnel is in Kabul.
==Russia== Russia provided a field hospital as well as a hospital in [[Kabul]] for allies and Afghan civilians.
Russia has also agreed to provide logistic support for the United States forces in Afghanistan to aid in anti-terrorist operations.
Russia is allowing U.S. and NATO forces to pass through its territory to go to Afghanistan.
Russian Special Forces has also assisted U.S. and Afghan forces in operations in Afghanistan, by helping with intel and studying the lay of the land.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://vodpod.com/watch/4796118-russia-back-to-afghanistan-to-help-us-nato# |title=Archived copy |access-date=25 February 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101102153933/http://vodpod.com/watch/4796118-russia-back-to-afghanistan-to-help-us-nato# |archive-date=2 November 2010 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Slovakia== Slovakia provided sappers and specialists on maintenance and reconstruction of airports and technical equipment for such operations.
==Slovenia== Slovenia deployed from 60–90 troops in Afghanistan and several IFVs ([[Infantry fighting vehicles]]) and armoured transport vehicles, and it is considering the possibility of deploying three attack helicopters.
==South Korea== South Korea provided logistical support and a field hospital.
==Spain== As a NATO member, Spain supported the invocation of Article V of the NATO charter. Spain made available Spanish military bases for military operations. Spanish forces have since supported the ISAF mission with about 2,500 combat troops in Afghanistan plus a helicopter detachment and 3 C-130 Hercules aircraft.
==Sudan== Sudan offered heavy and lightweight logistic support.
==Sweden== Sweden has been in Afghanistan since 2002 and has 900 soldiers there (February 2012). These troops are however NOT part of OEF, but are under the lead of ISAF. Sweden leads the [[PRT Mazari Sharif]]
==Switzerland== In its first military deployment since 1815, Switzerland deployed 31 soldiers to Afghanistan in 2003, and two Swiss officers had worked with German troops. Swiss forces were withdrawn in February 2008.
==Tajikistan== Tajikistan provided use of its airspace, airbases and facilities for humanitarian aid.
==Thailand== Thailand offered America and its allies a fueling station for aircraft and provided logistical support.
==Turkey== Turkey offered the United States use of its airspace and air refuelling for US aircraft deploying to the region. Turkey would later deploy troops to Afghanistan as part of ISAF.
Turkey also provided logistical support.
==Turkmenistan== Turkmenistan offered the use of its airspace.
==United Arab Emirates== The United Arab Emirates provided 3 security personnel. Special Forces are also in Afghanistan (Wikileaks) and [[Al Minhad Air Base]] is a support hub for Australia, New Zealand, and previously Canadian air forces.
==Ukraine== Ukraine allowed use of its airspace and airbases to America and its allies, but only for cargo flights. Ukraine is a participant in the NATO led [[International Security Assistance Force]] in Afghanistan and has deployed troops as part of NATO's ISAF mission to the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nato.int/ISAF/structure/nations/index.html|publisher=NATO|title=ISAF Troop Contributing Nations|access-date=29 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304114607/http://www.nato.int/ISAF/structure/nations/index.html#|archive-date=4 March 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==United Kingdom== {{Main|Operation Herrick}} The United Kingdom deployed sea, air and land assets for the invasion against the Taliban/al-Qaeda in 2001, designated [[Operation Veritas]]. The naval element consisted of one [[Invincible-class aircraft carrier|''Invincible''-class aircraft carrier]], one [[Landing Platform Dock|amphibious ship]], one [[destroyer]], one frigate, three nuclear fleet [[submarine]]s and seven [[Royal Fleet Auxiliary|Royal Fleet Auxiliaries]]. The submarines [[HMS Trafalgar (S107)|HMS ''Trafalga''r]] and [[HMS Triumph (S93)|HMS ''Triumph'']] launched [[Tomahawk (missile)|Tomahawk missile]]s on targets inside Afghanistan. [[Special Boat Service]] and [[Special Air Service]] special forces also deployed. Later [[45 Commando]], [[Royal Marines]] deployed as part of Operation Jacana. The [[Royal Air Force]] contributed [[Lockheed L-1011 TriStar]] and [[Vickers VC10]] tanker aircraft, [[Boeing E-3 Sentry]] surveillance and control aircraft, [[Hawker Siddeley Nimrod]] surveillance aircraft, [[Hawker Siddeley Nimrod#MR2|Nimrod MR2]] maritime reconnaissance aircraft, [[English Electric Canberra]] reconnaissance aircraft, [[Lockheed C-130 Hercules]] air transport aircraft and [[Boeing Chinook (UK variants)|Boeing Chinook]] helicopters from [[No. 27 Squadron RAF|27 Squadron]]. A total of 453 members of the British Armed Forces have died during OEF (see [[British forces casualties in Afghanistan since 2001|British forces casualties in Afghanistan]]).
Since initial deployments supporting OEF, British forces have taken part in the ISAF mission, whilst British special forces have worked with both OEF and ISAF. In January 2006, Defence Secretary [[John Reid, Baron Reid of Cardowan|John Reid]] announced the UK would send a PRT with several thousand personnel to Helmand for at least three years. This had been planned as part of the gradual expansion of ISAF's area of responsibility from the Kabul region to the rest of Afghanistan. An initial strength of 5,700 personnel in Afghanistan was planned, which would stabilise to around 4,500 for the rest of the deployment.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200506/cmhansrd/cm060126/debtext/60126-10.htm#column_1529 |title="House of Commons Hansard Debates for 26 January 2006" |access-date=7 September 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170905142545/https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200506/cmhansrd/cm060126/debtext/60126-10.htm#column_1529#column_1529 |archive-date=5 September 2017 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==United States of America== In 2002, there were approximately 7,000 troops in Afghanistan, including [[United States Army Rangers]], troops from the [[10th Mountain Division]], 187th Infantry Regt. "Rakkasans" 101st Airborne (Air Assault), [[82nd Airborne]] and [[US Marines]]. Marines of the [[15th Marine Expeditionary Unit]] and [[26th Marine Expeditionary Unit]] were among the first conventional forces into Afghanistan in support of [[Operation Enduring Freedom]] on 25 November 2001. The 1-87th IN, 10th Mountain Division deployed elements assisting special forces elements on 25 or 26 Nov at Mazaar Sharif and securing Bagram airfield from British special forces.
The [[United States Navy]] aircraft carrier [[USS Enterprise (CVN 65)|USS ''Enterprise'']] with an 8 ship and submarine task group, followed by the [[USS Carl Vinson (CVN-70)|USS ''Carl Vinson'']] with 9 other ships and submarines, deployed for operations over Afghanistan at different stages to the end of 2002. The USS ''Theodore Roosevelt'' (CVN-71) with an 11 ship and submarine task group also deployed. Additionally The USS ''George Washington'' (CVN 73) was deployed from 20 June 2002 until 20 December 2002 in support of Operation Southern Watch, and Operation Enduring Freedom.
Roughly 150 aircraft were initially deployed for Operation Enduring Freedom, including some two dozen [[Boeing B-52]] bombers and support aircraft.
In 2007, 23,000 American troops were in Afghanistan, in the OEF-A. Other US troops are in [[International Security Assistance Force|ISAF]].
==Uzbekistan== [[Uzbekistan]] had allowed the U.S. to place troops on the ground as well as use the Uzbek airbase, K2, for support activities and for deployment and command and control of Special Forces into all of Afghanistan except for the Khandahar region. K2 is no longer in use by the U.S.
==See also== * [[Civilian casualties of the war in Afghanistan (2001–present)]] * [[Protests against the invasion of Afghanistan]] * [[Canadian Afghan detainee abuse scandal]] * [[Coalition casualties in Afghanistan]] * [[British forces casualties in Afghanistan]] * [[Canadian Forces casualties in Afghanistan]] * [[German Armed Forces casualties in Afghanistan]] * [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)]] * [[Criticism of the War on Terrorism]]

{{about||the anniversary of the beginning of the American Revolution and the holiday celebrated in Massachusetts, Maine, and other states|Patriots' Day|the Quebec holiday|National Patriots' Day}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = Patriot Day |type = |image = |imagesize = |caption = |official_name = |nickname = |observedby = United States |litcolor = |longtype = |significance = |begins = |ends = |date = September 11 |mdy = yes |scheduling = same day each year |duration = 1 day |frequency = annual |celebrations = |observances = |relatedto = }} {{multiple image | direction = vertical | width = 200 | footer = | image2 = Patriot Day.jpg | alt2 = | caption2 = [[President of the United States|President]] [[George W. Bush]] and [[Vice President of the United States|Vice President]] [[Dick Cheney]] on September 11, 2004 lead a moment of silence on the [[South Lawn (White House)|South Lawn]] with [[White House]] staff and families of [[September 11 attacks|victims of 9/11]]. }} In the [[United States]], '''Patriot Day''' occurs on September 11 of each year in memory of the [[Casualties of the September 11 attacks|people killed]] in the [[September 11 attacks]] of the year 2001.
==History== In the immediate aftermath of the attacks, [[President of the United States|President]] [[George W. Bush]], proclaimed Friday September 14, 2001, as a '''National Day of Prayer and Remembrance for the Victims of the Terrorist Attacks on September 11, 2001'''.<ref>[https://georgewbush-whitehouse.archives.gov/news/releases/2001/09/20010913-7.html National Day of Prayer and Remembrance for the Victims Of the Terrorist Attacks on September 11, 2001] A Proclamation by the President of the United States of America</ref>
A bill to make September 11 a [[national day of mourning]] was introduced in the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. House]] on October 25, 2001, by Rep. [[Vito Fossella]] (R-NY) with 22 co-sponsors, among them 11 [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]] and 11 [[Republican Party (United States)|Republicans]].<ref name="thomas.loc.gov">{{cite web |url=http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d107:HJ00071:@@@L&summ2=m&#cosponsors |title=Bill Summary & Status 107th Congress (2001–2002) H.J.RES.71 All Information – Office of the Clerk |accessdate=June 16, 2012}}</ref> The bill requested that the President designate September 11 of each year as '''Patriot Day'''. Joint Resolution 71 passed the House by a vote of 407–0, with 25 members not voting.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2001/roll407.xml |title=Final Vote Results for Roll Call 407 |publisher=[[Clerk of the United States House of Representatives|Office of the Clerk]] |accessdate=May 28, 2007}}</ref> The bill passed the Senate unanimously on November 30. President Bush signed the resolution into law on December 18 as {{USPL|107|89}}.<ref>[http://frwebgate.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/getdoc.cgi?dbname=107_cong_public_laws&docid=f:publ089.107 Public Law 107-89]</ref> On September 4, 2002, President Bush used the authority of the resolution to proclaim September 11, 2002, as the first Patriot Day.
Original co-sponsors in the House were:<ref name="thomas.loc.gov"/> {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Gary Ackerman]] (D-NY) *[[Rick Boucher]] (D-VA) *[[Eliot L. Engel]] (D-NY) *[[Phil English]] (R-PA) *[[Randy Forbes]] (R-VA) *[[Benjamin A. Gilman]] (R-NY) *[[Felix Grucci]] (R-NY) *[[Maurice Hinchey]] (D-NY) *[[Steve Israel]] (D-NY) *[[Peter T. King]] (R-NY) *[[Ray LaHood]] (R-IL) *[[Nita Lowey]] (D-NY) *[[Carolyn B. Maloney]] (D-NY) *[[Michael R. McNulty]] (D-NY) *[[Jim Moran]] (D-VA) *[[Jerrold Nadler]] (D-NY) *[[John E. Peterson]] (R-PA) *[[Thomas M. Reynolds]] (R-NY) *[[Ed Schrock]] (R-VA) *[[Don Sherwood]] (R-PA) *[[Edolphus Towns|Ed Towns]] (D-NY) *[[James T. Walsh]] (R-NY) {{div col end}}
From 2009 to 2016, President [[Barack Obama]] proclaimed September 11 as '''Patriot Day and National Day of Service and Remembrance''', in observance of {{USPL|111|13}}, the [[Edward M. Kennedy Serve America Act]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the_press_office/Presidential-Proclamation-Patriot-Day-and-National-Day-of-Remembrance-and-Service/ |title=Presidential Proclamation: Patriot Day and National Day of Service and Remembrance |publisher=[[White House Office of the Press Secretary]] |date=September 10, 2009 |accessdate=September 10, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140918170033/http://www.whitehouse.gov/the_press_office/Presidential-Proclamation-Patriot-Day-and-National-Day-of-Remembrance-and-Service/ |archivedate=September 18, 2014 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2010/09/10/presidential-proclamation-patriot-day-and-national-day-service-and-remem |title=Presidential Proclamation: Patriot Day and National Day of Service and Remembrance |publisher=[[White House Office of the Press Secretary]] |date=September 10, 2010 |accessdate=September 10, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2011/09/09/presidential-proclamation-patriot-day-and-national-day-service-and-remem |title=Presidential Proclamation: Patriot Day and National Day of Service and Remembrance |publisher=[[White House Office of the Press Secretary]] |date=September 9, 2011 |accessdate=September 10, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2012/09/10/presidential-proclamation-patriot-day-and-national-day-service-and-remem |title=Presidential Proclamation: Patriot Day and National Day of Service and Remembrance |publisher=[[White House Office of the Press Secretary]] |date=September 10, 2012 |accessdate=September 10, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2013/09/10/presidential-proclamation-patriot-day-and-national-day-service-and-remem |title=Presidential Proclamation: Patriot Day and National Day of Service and Remembrance |publisher=[[White House Office of the Press Secretary]] |date=September 11, 2013 |accessdate=September 10, 2014}}</ref>
In 2017 and 2018, President [[Donald Trump]] proclaimed September 8–10 as '''National Days of Prayer and Remembrance''',<ref>{{cite news|last1=[[White House Office of the Press Secretary|Office of the Press Secretary]]|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2017/09/08/president-donald-j-trump-proclaims-friday-september-8-2017-through|title=President Donald J. Trump Proclaims Friday, September 8, 2017, through Sunday, September 10, 2017, as National Days of Prayer and Remembrance|work=[[whitehouse.gov]]|publisher=[[White House]]|location=[[Washington, D.C.]]|language=en|date=September 8, 2017|accessdate=September 20, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite tweet|user=WhiteHouse|last1=White House|authorlink=White House|number=906276718582915072|date=September 8, 2017|title=President Donald J. Trump Proclaims Fri, Sept 8, 2017 - Sun, Sept 10, 2017 as National Days of Prayer & Remembrance:|link=https://twitter.com/whitehouse/status/906276718582915072|accessdate=September 20, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2017/09/14/2017-19739/national-days-of-prayer-and-remembrance-2017|title=National Days of Prayer and Remembrance, 2017|work=[[Federal Register]]|publisher=[[National Archives and Records Administration]]|location=[[Washington, D.C.]]|date=September 8, 2017|accessdate=September 20, 2017|archiveurl=https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/FR-2017-09-14/pdf/2017-19739.pdf|archivedate=September 14, 2017}}</ref> and proclaimed September 11 as '''Patriot Day'''.<ref>{{cite news|last1=[[White House Office of the Press Secretary|Office of the Press Secretary]]|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2017/09/08/president-donald-j-trump-proclaims-september-11-2017-patriot-day|title=President Donald J. Trump Proclaims September 11, 2017, as Patriot Day|work=[[whitehouse.gov]]|publisher=[[White House]]|location=[[Washington, D.C.]]|language=en|date=September 8, 2017|accessdate=September 21, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite tweet|user=WhiteHouse|last1=White House|authorlink=White House|number=907288383445225473|date=September 8, 2017|title=President Donald J. Trump Proclaims September 11, 2017, as Patriot Day:|link=https://twitter.com/whitehouse/status/907288383445225473|accessdate=September 21, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/01/20/trump-to-proclaim-national-day-of-patriotism-spokesman-says.html|title=Trump to proclaim National Day of Patriotism, spokesman say|first=Christine|last=Wang|work=[[CNBC]]|publisher=[[NBCUniversal News Group]]|location=[[Englewood Cliffs, New Jersey]]|date=|accessdate=September 21, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2017/09/14/2017-19740/patriot-day-2017|title=Patriot Day, 2017|work=[[Federal Register]]|publisher=[[National Archives and Records Administration]]|location=[[Washington, D.C.]]|date=September 8, 2017|accessdate=September 21, 2017|archiveurl=https://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/FR-2017-09-14/pdf/2017-19740.pdf|archivedate=September 14, 2017}}</ref>
==Observance== {{more citations needed|section|date=September 2017}} [[File:Union Station 2013-09-11 A.JPG|thumb|right|In Washington, D.C., three [[Flag of the United States|American flags]] fly at [[half-staff]] on [[Columbus Circle (Washington, D.C.)|Columbus Circle]] (outside of [[Union Station (Washington, D.C.)|Union Station]]) on Patriot Day 2013. The flags of several US states and territories can be seen also flying at half-staff [[:File:Union Station 2013-09-11 B.JPG|in the background]].]]
The [[flag of the United States]] is flown at [[half-staff]] at the White House and on all [[Federal government of the United States|U.S. government]] buildings and establishments throughout the world; flags are also encouraged to be displayed on individual American homes. Additionally, a [[moment of silence]] is observed to correspond with the attacks, beginning at 8:46 a.m. ([[Eastern Time Zone|Eastern Daylight Time]]), the time the first plane, [[American Airlines Flight 11]], struck the North Tower of the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]] on September 11, 2001.
Patriot Day is not a [[Federal holidays in the United States|federal holiday]]; schools and businesses remain open in observance of the occasion, although memorial ceremonies for the victims are often held. Volunteer and service opportunities are coordinated by the [[Corporation for National and Community Service]].

[[Image:PJBlok.jpg|150px|thumb|Petrus Johannes Blok
Painting by [[Thérèse Schwartze]] ]] '''Petrus Johannes Blok''' ([[Den Helder]], 10 January 1855 – [[Leiden]], 24 October 1929) was a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[history|historian]]. ==Biography== Born in [[Den Helder]], Blok studied at the [[Latin school|Latin School]] of [[Alkmaar]] and read [[classics]] at [[Leiden University]], receiving his [[Doctor of Philosophy|doctorate]] for a study of [[Sextus Pompeius]]. After this, he got a position at the [[Stedelijk Gymnasium Leiden|Leiden Latin School]], and published two books on the city's [[Middle Ages|Medieval]] and [[Burgundian Netherlands|Burgundian]] history. In 1884, he was made [[professor]] of [[History of the Netherlands|Dutch History]] at the [[University of Groningen]], where he supervised the publication of a series of historical documents from the provinces of [[Groningen (province)|Groningen]] and [[Drenthe]]. He was in the habit of traveling much to search for written documents, which brought him as far as [[Rome]]: a very long trip back then. Among his students was [[Pieter Jelles Troelstra]]. In 1892, Blok was elected a member of the [[Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences]].{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.dwc.knaw.nl/biografie/pmknaw/?pagetype=authorDetail&aId=PE00002815 |title=Petrus Johannes Blok (1855 - 1929) |publisher=Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences |date= |accessdate=22 May 2016}} In 1894, he succeeded [[Robert Fruin]] as professor of Dutch History in Leiden. ==Ideas== Blok believed that it was the task of a historian to stress a country's ''national'' past and contribute to a sense of unity. It does not come as a surprise that he was one of the editors of the ''[[Nieuw Nederlandsch Biografisch Woordenboek]]'' ("New Dutch Biographical Dictionary"). His books are biographical in nature and are about Dutch heroes: ''[[William the Silent|Oranje]]'' (1919–1920), ''[[Frederik Hendrik]]'' (1924), and ''[[Michiel de Ruyter|De Ruyter]]'' (1928). His work, the ''Geschiedenis van het Nederlandsche volk'', consists of eight volumes, published between 1892 and 1907. It is really a history of a nation – with its arts, economy, religions, laws, and daily life – and not the story of a state. It is a book about people, but not a real social history; Blok's magnum opus has unfavorably been compared to [[Henri Pirenne|Pirenne]]'s famous ''[[Histoire de Belgique (book)|Histoire de Belgique]]'' (1909–1932). (The English translation, by [[Ruth Putnam (author)|Ruth Putnam]] and Oscar A. Bierstadt, of Blok's book, ''History of the people of the Netherlands'', is abridged and has five volumes.) ==Legacy== His ideas about history as an instrument of [[nation building]] have for a long time been out of fashion among academicians, but returned very much to the center of the Dutch public debate in 2006, when politician [[Jan Marijnissen]] argued for the creation of a Museum of National History. His proposal was accepted in 2008, but ultimately the museum didn't materialize. Blok is the spiritual father of the Dutch Institute in the [[Villa Borghese gardens]], which he founded in 1904. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{nl icon}} [http://www.dbnl.org/tekst/_jaa003193001_01/_jaa003193001_01_0033.htm Biography at DNBL] * [http://www.knir.it/ Royal Netherlands Institute in Rome] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Blok, Petrus Johannes}} [[Category:1855 births]] [[Category:1929 deaths]] [[Category:Dutch historians]] [[Category:People from Den Helder]] [[Category:Leiden University alumni]] [[Category:Members of the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences]] [[Category:Members of Teylers Tweede Genootschap]]
